without any impediment,ཚེ་རབས་ཀུན་ཏུ་དམ་ཆོས་སྤྱོད་པར་ཤོག། Putting the genuine Dharma into practice throughout all my lives.ལུང་རིག་ཐོས་པས་མི་ཤེས་སྒྲིབ་ལས་གྲོལ།། Study of scripture and reasoning liberates from the veils of unknowing;མན་ངག་བསམ་པས་ཐེ་ཚོམ་མུན་ནག་བཅོམ།། Contemplating instructions overcomes the dense darkness of doubt;སྒོམ་བྱུང་འོད་ཀྱིས་གནས་ལུགས་ཇི་བཞིན་གསལ།། And the light arisen from meditation illuminates reality just as it is—ཤེས་རབ་གསུམ་གྱི་སྣང་བ་རྒྱས་པར་ཤོག། May the radiance of these three forms of wisdom expand and increase.རྟག་ཆད་མཐའ་བྲལ་བདེན་གཉིས་གཞི་ཡི་དོན།། The ground is the two truths, free from eternalist and nihilistic extremes;སྒྲོ་སྐུར་མཐའ་བྲལ་ཚོགས་གཉིས་ལམ་མཆོག་གིས།། The supreme path, twofold accumulation, unlimited by projection and denial,སྲིད་ཞིའི་མཐའ་བྲལ་དོན་གཉིས་འབྲས་ཐོབ་པའི།། Brings the fruition, twofold benefit, free from the extremes of existence and quiescence—གོལ་འཆུག་མེད་པའི་ཆོས་དང་ཕྲད་པར་ཤོག། May I encounter this Dharma that is without error or confusion.སྦྱང་གཞི་སེམས་ཉིད་གསལ་སྟོང་ཟུང་འཇུག་ལ།། Upon the basis of purification, mind’s nature of clarity and emptiness in union,སྦྱོང་བྱེད་ཕྱག་ཆེན་རྡོ་རྗེའི་རྣལ་འབྱོར་ཆེས།། May that which purifies, the great adamantine yoga of Mahāmudrā,སྦྱང་བྱ་གློ་བུར་འཁྲུལ་པའི་དྲི་མ་རྣམས།། Purify its objects, the stains of adventitious delusion,སྦྱངས་འབྲས་དྲི་བྲལ་ཆོས་སྐུ་མངོན་འགྱུར་ཤོག། And, as a result, may I realize the immaculate dharmakāya.གཞི་ལ་སྒྲོ་འདོགས་ཆོད་པ་ལྟ་བའི་གདེངས།། Eliminating misconceptions of the ground brings assurance in the view;དེ་ལ་མ་ཡེངས་སྐྱོང་བ་སྒོམ་པའི་གནད།། To sustain that view without distraction is the key point of meditation;སྒོམ་དོན་ཀུན་ལ་རྩལ་སྦྱོང་སྤྱོད་པའི་མཆོག། And to train in all of meditation’s facets is the supreme form of action—ལྟ་སྒོམ་སྤྱོད་པའི་གདེང་དང་ལྡན་པར་ཤོག། May I possess the confident assurance of view, meditation and conduct.ཆོས་རྣམས་ཐམས་ཅད་སེམས་ཀྱི་རྣམ་འཕྲུལ་ཏེ།། All phenomena are but apparitions of the mind;སེམས་ནི་སེམས་མེད་སེམས་ཀྱི་ངོ་བོས་སྟོང་།། Mind itself is without mind, empty of mind’s essence—སྟོང་ཞིང་མ་འགགས་ཅིར་ཡང་སྣང་བ་སྟེ།། Empty yet unrestricted, appearing in any way at all.ལེགས་པར་བརྟག་ནས་གཞི་རྩ་ཆོད་པར་ཤོག། Having examined it well, may I determine the basis.ཡོད་མ་མྱོང་བའི་རང་སྣང་ཡུལ་དུ་འཁྲུལ།། I mistake my own perceptions, which have never been real, for objects,མ་རིག་དབང་གིས་རང་རིག་བདག་ཏུ་འཁྲུལ།། And through ignorance’s power, confuse my own awareness for a self.གཉིས་འཛིན་དབང་གིས་སྲིད་པའི་ཀློང་དུ་འཁྱམས།། Through duality’s force, I roam the arena of saṃsāric existence.མ་རིག་འཁྲུལ་པའི་རྩད་བརྡར་ཆོད་པར་ཤོག། May I thoroughly eradicate ignorance and delusion.ཡོད་པ་མ་ཡིན་རྒྱལ་བས་ཀྱང་མ་གཟིགས།། It is not existent, for even the buddhas have not seen it.མེད་པ་མ་ཡིན་འཁོར་འདས་ཀུན་གྱི་གཞི།། It is not nonexistent, for it’s the basis of all saṃsāra and nirvāṇa.འགལ་འདུ་མ་ཡིན་ཟུང་འཇུག་དབུ་མའི་ལམ།། This is not a contradiction; it’s the middle way of unity.མཐའ་བྲལ་སེམས་ཀྱི་ཆོས་ཉིད་རྟོགས་པར་ཤོག། May I realize mind’s nature, free from limiting extremes.འདི་ཡིན་ཞེས་པ་གང་གིས་མཚོན་པ་མེད།། There is nothing to point to, saying, “It is this.”འདི་མིན་ཞེས་བྱ་གང་གིས་བཀག་པ་མེད།། Nor can there be denial as in, “This it is not.”བློ་ལས་འདས་པའི་ཆོས་ཉིད་འདུས་མ་བྱས།། Dharmatā, beyond the mind, is uncompounded.ཡང་དག་དོན་གྱི་མཐའ་ནི་ངེས་པར་ཤོག། May I determine the bounds of genuine reality.འདི་ཉིད་མ་རྟོགས་འཁོར་བའི་རྒྱ་མཚོར་འཁོར།། Not realizing this, I drift about in saṃsāra’s ocean.འདི་ཉིད་རྟོགས་ན་སངས་རྒྱས་གཞན་ན་མེད།། When I do realize it, buddhahood lies nowhere else.ཐམས་ཅད་འདི་ཡིན་འདི་མིན་གང་ཡང་མེད།། Everything is this; there is nothing else besides.ཆོས་ཉིད་ཀུན་གཞིའི་མཚང་ནི་རིག་པར་ཤོག། May I know the hidden point of the all-ground, dharmatā.སྣང་ཡང་སེམས་ལ་སྟོང་ཡང་སེམས་ཡིན་ཏེ།། Appearances are mind; emptiness is also the mind.རྟོགས་ཀྱང་སེམས་ལ་འཁྲུལ་ཡང་རང་གི་སེམས།། Realization is mind; delusion too is one’s own mind.སྐྱེས་ཀྱང་སེམས་ལ་འགགས་ཀྱང་སེམས་ཡིན་པས།། What’s arisen is mind; what’s ceased is also mind.སྒྲོ་འདོགས་ཐམས་ཅད་སེམས་ལ་ཆོད་པར་ཤོག། May I eliminate all misconceptions within the mind.བློས་བྱས་རྩོལ་བའི་སྒོམ་གྱིས་མ་བསླད་ཅིང་།། Unspoilt by deliberate, mind-fabricated meditation,ཐ་མལ་འདུ་འཛིའི་རླུང་གིས་མ་བསྐྱོད་པར།། And unswayed by the winds of ordinary preoccupation,མ་བཅོས་གཉུག་མ་རང་བབ་འཇོག་ཤེས་པའི།། May I learn how to settle naturally without contrivance,སེམས་དོན་ཉམས་ལེན་མཁས་ཤིང་སྐྱོང་བར་ཤོག། And skilfully sustain the practice of mind’s ultimate point.ཕྲ་རག་རྟོག་པའི་དབའ་རླབས་རང་སར་ཞི།། With waves of coarse and subtle thought naturally calmed,གཡོ་མེད་སེམས་ཀྱི་ཆུ་བོ་ངང་གིས་གནས།། And the river of mind unmoving, spontaneously stilled;བྱིང་རྨུགས་རྙོག་པའི་དྲི་མ་དང་བྲལ་བའི།། Uncontaminated by the taints of lethargy and dullness,ཞི་གནས་རྒྱ་མཚོ་མི་གཡོ་བརྟན་པར་ཤོག། May the ocean of śamatha remain steadfastly inert.བལྟར་མེད་སེམས་ལ་ཡང་ཡང་བལྟས་པའི་ཚེ།། When looking repeatedly at unobservable mind,མཐོང་མེད་དོན་ནི་ཇི་བཞིན་ལྷག་གེར་མཐོང་།། The point of non-seeing is vividly seen, just as it is.ཡིན་མིན་དོན་ལ་ཐེ་ཚོམ་ཆོད་པ་ཉིད།། And indecision—is it? or is it not?—is cut right through.འཁྲུལ་མེད་རང་ངོ་རང་གིས་ཤེས་པར་ཤོག། May I recognize my very own nature, without delusion.ཡུལ་ལ་བལྟས་པས་ཡུལ་མེད་སེམས་སུ་མཐོང་།། Looking at objects, I see them as objectless mind;སེམས་ལ་བལྟས་པས་སེམས་མེད་ངོ་བོས་སྟོང་།། Looking at mind, mind is absent, empty of essence;གཉིས་ལ་བལྟས་པས་གཉིས་འཛིན་རང་སར་གྲོལ།། Looking at both, duality is liberated there and then—འོད་གསལ་སེམས་ཀྱི་གནས་ལུགས་རྟོགས་པར་ཤོག། May I realize mind’s true nature, which is clear light.ཡིད་བྱེད་བྲལ་བ་འདི་ནི་ཕྱག་རྒྱ་ཆེ།། This absence of mental engagement is Mahāmudrā.མཐའ་དང་བྲལ་བ་དབུ་མ་ཆེན་པོ་ཡིན།། The freedom from extremes is the great Middle Way.འདི་ནི་ཀུན་འདུས་རྫོགས་ཆེན་ཞེས་ཀྱང་བྱ།། Since all is here included, it is also Great Perfection.གཅིག་ཤེས་ཀུན་དོན་རྟོགས་པའི་གདེང་ཐོབ་ཤོག། May I acquire the confidence of knowing one and realizing all.ཞེན་པ་མེད་པའི་བདེ་ཆེན་རྒྱུན་ཆད་མེད།། Great bliss without attachment continues uninterruptedly;མཚན་འཛིན་མེད་པའི་འོད་གསལ་སྒྲིབ་གཡོགས་བྲལ།། Clear light without conceptual identification is unobscured;བློ་ལས་འདས་པའི་མི་རྟོག་ལྷུན་གྱིས་གྲུབ།། Non-conceptuality beyond the mind is spontaneously present—རྩོལ་མེད་ཉམས་མྱོང་རྒྱུན་ཆད་མེད་པར་ཤོག། May effortless experience emerge in a never-ending flow.བཟང་ཞེན་ཉམས་ཀྱི་འཛིན་པ་རང་སར་གྲོལ།། Attachment to positive experience is liberated of its own accord;ངན་རྟོག་འཁྲུལ་པ་རང་བཞིན་དབྱིངས་སུ་དག། Negative thinking and delusion are purified within the natural expanse;ཐ་མལ་ཤེས་པ་སྤང་བླང་བྲལ་ཐོབ་མེད།། And ordinary awareness is neither shunned nor sought, neither lost nor gained—སྤྲོས་བྲལ་ཆོས་ཉིད་བདེན་པ་རྟོགས་པར་ཤོག། May I realize the truth of dharmatā that is beyond conceptual elaboration.འགྲོ་བའི་རང་བཞིན་རྟག་ཏུ་སངས་རྒྱས་ཀྱང་།། Although beings’ true nature has always been awakened,མ་རྟོགས་དབང་གིས་མཐའ་མེད་འཁོར་བར་འཁྱམས།། In their non-recognition, they wander in saṃsāra without end.སྡུག་བསྔལ་མུ་མཐའ་མེད་པའི་སེམས་ཅན་ལ།། For these sentient beings whose misery knows no bounds,བཟོད་མེད་སྙིང་རྗེ་རྒྱུད་ལ་སྐྱེ་བར་ཤོག། May I develop a compassion that is unbearably intense.བཟོད་མེད་སྙིང་རྗེའི་རྩལ་ཡང་མ་འགགས་པའི།། The strength of unbearable compassion is unrestricted,བརྩེ་དུས་ངོ་བོ་སྟོང་དོན་རྗེན་པར་ཤར།། And in this love, the reality of the empty essence laid bare.ཟུང་འཇུག་གོལ་ས་བྲལ་བའི་ལམ་མཆོག་འདི།། May I constantly cultivate this supreme, unerring path of unityའབྲལ་མེད་ཉིན་མཚན་ཀུན་ཏུ་སྒོམ་པར་ཤོག། And may I never be apart from it, by day or by night.སྒོམ་སྟོབས་ལས་བྱུང་སྤྱན་དང་མངོན་ཤེས་དང་།། With sight and heightened perception born of meditation,སེམས་ཅན་སྨིན་བྱས་སངས་རྒྱས་ཞིང་རབ་སྦྱངས།། May I bring beings to maturity, fully purify buddha realms,སངས་རྒྱས་ཆོས་རྣམས་འགྲུབ་པའི་སྨོན་ལམ་རྫོགས།། And fulfil the aspirations to accomplish a buddha’s qualities—རྫོགས་སྨིན་སྦྱངས་གསུམ་མཐར་ཕྱིན་སངས་རྒྱས་ཤོག། Thus may I awaken, with perfecting, maturing and purifying all complete.ཕྱོགས་བཅུའི་རྒྱལ་བ་སྲས་བཅས་ཐུགས་རྗེ་དང་།། Through the compassion of the buddhas and their heirs in every direction,རྣམ་དཀར་དགེ་བ་ཇི་སྙེད་ཡོད་པའི་མཐུས།། And the power of whatever wholesome virtue there might be,དེ་ལྟར་བདག་དང་སེམས་ཅན་ཐམས་ཅད་ཀྱི།། May my own and all other beings’ purest aspirationsསྨོན་ལམ་རྣམ་དག་ཇི་བཞིན་འགྲུབ་གྱུར་ཅིག། Be fulfilled, exactly in accordance with our wishes. ཅེས་ངེས་དོན་ཕྱག་རྒྱ་ཆེན་པོའི་སྨོན་ལམ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་རྗེ་ཀརྨ་པ་རང་བྱུང་རྡོ་རྗེས་མཛད་པའོ།།།། This Aspiration of the Mahāmudrā of Definitive Meaning was composed by Lord Karmapa Rangjung Dorje.

Dedication །ཐོག་མར་རང་ཉིད་དལ་འབྱོར་ཡོན་ཏན་ལ་དགའ་བ་བསྒོམ་པ་ནི། Begin by cultivating a sense of delight in the qualities of the freedoms and riches: །མི་ལུས་ཡོན་ཏན་དུ་མའི་བདག་ཉིད་ཅན། Seeing its many wonderful qualities,།ཡིན་པར་ཤེས་ནས་དགའ་སྤྲོ་རྗེས་ཡི་རངས། I rejoice and delight in this human life.
Level 1.1: Instructions for Contemplating Precious Human Life།ཆོས་རྣམས་མི་རྟག་བའི་རང་བཞིན་དུ་བསམ་ཏེ། Next, contemplate the impermanent nature of phenomena: །དངོས་རྣམས་མི་རྟག་རྒྱ་མཚོའི་རླབས་ཇི་བཞིན། Like waves in the ocean, all things are impermanent.།གང་བྱུང་དང་དུ་བླངས་ཏེ་གྲོགས་སུ་ཁྱེར། I will accept whatever happens and make it my friend.
Level 1.2: Instructions for Contemplating Impermanence།རྒྱུ་རྐྱེན་རྟེན་ཅིང་འབྲེལ་བར་འབྱུང་བར་བསམ་ཏེ། Contemplate the interdependence of causes and conditions: །རྒྱུ་རྐྱེན་འཛོམས་ན་འབྲས་བུ་ངེས་སྨིན་པས། When causes and conditions come together, a result is sure to follow,།ལེགས་ཚོགས་གཞན་ཕན་ལས་ལ་གང་ནུས་འབད། So I will do my best to help others and engage in positive deeds.
Level 1.3: Instructions for Contemplating Karma།འཁོར་བའི་སྡུག་བསྔལ་རྨི་ལམ་ལྟ་བུར་བསམ་ཏེ། Contemplate the dreamlike quality of the suffering of samsara: །འགྲོ་བའི་སྡུག་བསྔལ་གཙོ་བོ་སེམས་ཀྱིས་བྱས། The suffering of beings is mainly produced by the mind.།རང་ཉིད་རང་གི་བཅིང་ལས་གྲོལ་བར་བྱ། I must free myself from my self-created bonds.
Level 1.4: Instructions for Contemplating the Suffering of Samsara།འཁོར་བའི་སྡུག་བསྔལ་གྱི་མཚོ་ལས་གྲོལ་བའི་དེད་དཔོན་དཀོན་མཆོག་གསུམ་ཡིད་དུ་བྱས་ཏེ། Bring to mind the Three Jewels, the guides who will free you from the ocean of samsara's suffering: །མི་སླུ་གཏན་གྱི་སྐྱབས་གནས་དཀོན་མཆོག་གསུམ། Three Jewels, undeceiving and everlasting sources of refuge,།བདག་སོགས་སྟོན་པ་ལམ་དང་གྲོགས་མཛོད་ཅིག།། Please be the guide, the path, and companions for myself and all beings.
Level 2: Instructions for Practicing RefugeThen recite the following three lines as many times as you are able: །ན་མོ་བུ་དྡྷཱ་ཡ། །ན་མོ་དྷརྨཱ་ཡ། །ན་མོ་སངྒ་ཡ།། ཞེས་ཅི་ནུས་བཟླ། །དོན་དམ་སྐྱབས་གནས་རང་ལ་རྫོགས་པ་སྟེ། The ultimate refuge is perfectly complete within me,།སེམས་ཉིད་བདེ་གཤེགས་སྙིང་པོ་ཡེ་སངས་རྒྱས། For my mind is buddha nature, enlightened from the very start.།རང་ཉིད་ཇི་ལྟ་བུར་བདེ་སྡུག་བླང་དོར་གྱི་འདུན་པས་ཁྱབ་པའི་འགྲོ་བ་རྣམས་ལ་རང་གི་ནང་མི་བཞིན་དུ་ཡིད་དུ་བྱས་ཏེ་བྱམས་སྙིང་རྗེ་བསྒོམ་པ་ནི། Next, meditate on loving-kindness and compassion by thinking of all the infinite number of beings as members of your own family, recognizing that they share your wish to be happy and free from suffering: །རང་ཉིད་ཇི་བཞིན་བདེ་སྡུག་བླང་དོར་བློས། I feel compassion for all the beings།ཡོངས་སུ་ཁྱབ་པའི་འགྲོ་རྣམས་སྙིང་རེ་རྗེ། Who, like me, want to be happy and free from suffering.།བདག་གིས་མཁའ་ཁྱབ་ཀྱི་སེམས་ཅན་སངས་རྒྱས་ས་ལ་འགོད་པའི་ཆེད་ལམ་ཉམས་སུ་ལེན་པར་བྱའོ་སྙམ་ནས་བྱང་ཆུབ་ཏུ་སེམས་བསྐྱེད་པ་ནི། Generate bodhichitta, thinking to yourself, "I will practice on the path to bring all the infinite number of beings to the state of buddhahood." །ཀུན་ཀྱང་རྣམ་མཁྱེན་རྒྱལ་བའི་གོ་འཕངས་ལ། To bring all beings to the state of omniscient buddhahood,།བདག་གིས་འགོད་ཕྱིར་ལམ་ལ་འཇུག་པར་བྱ།། I will now practice the path.
།མདུན་གྱི་ནམ་མཁར་ངོ་བོ་རང་གི་བླ་མ་ལ་རྣམ་པར་རྡོ་རྗེ་འཆང་སོགས་རང་ཉིད་གང་མོས་ཀྱི་སངས་རྒྱས་སུ་བསྒོམ་ཏེ།
In the space before you, imagine your own guru in the form of Vajradhara or whichever buddha inspires you. །བླ་མའི་ངོ་བོ་སངས་རྒྱས་ཀུན་དང་མཉམ། Think of me, O Guru. In essence, you are equal to all the buddhas,།ལྷག་པར་བདག་ལ་བཀའ་དྲིན་ཆེ་བ་མཁྱེན། But in the kindness you have shown me, you are even greater. །བླ་མ་མཁྱེན་ནོ།། །ཞེས་ཅེ་ནུས་བརྗོད། Think of me, O Guru.།བླ་མ་འོད་དུ་ཞུ་ནས་རང་ལ་ཐིམ་ཞིང་རང་དང་བླ་མ་ཐུགས་ཡིད་དབྱེར་མེད་དུ་འདྲེས་པར་མོས་ཏེ། Imagine that the guru melts into light and dissolves into you, your minds merging indivisibly. །དོན་དམ་རང་ཡང་བླ་མའི་ངོ་བོར་རྫོགས། Ultimately, I am the same as the guru in essence,།སློབ་མའི་རང་བཞིན་སངས་རྒྱས་ཀུན་དང་མཉམ། For the nature of the student is the same as that of all the buddhas.།མཐར་རང་དང་བླ་མ་སངས་རྒྱས་གསུམ་ངོ་བོ་དབྱེར་མེད་ཀྱི་ངང་དུ་མ་བསྒོམ་པ་ལ་ཡེངས་སུ་ཡང་མ་ཤོར་བར་སེམས་རང་བབ་གནས་ལུགས་ཐ་མལ་རང་ག་མའི་རྒྱུན་སྐྱོང་ཏེ། To conclude, let the mind rest naturally, without meditating yet undistracted, in the state in which you, the guru, and the buddhas are indivisible in essence. Maintain the flow of the mind's true nature — ordinary, just as it is. །རང་དང་བླ་མ་སངས་རྒྱས་ཀུན་གྱི་ཐུགས། My mind inseparable from the minds of the guru and all the buddhas,།དབྱེར་མེད་མ་བཅོས་རང་བབ་གཉུག་མའི་གཤིས། I rest naturally, without fabrication, in my basic nature,།མ་ཡེངས་མི་སྒོམ་བཟོ་མེད་རང་ག་མ། Not meditating and not distracted, in uncontrived ordinariness.།རིག་པ་རང་ཉིད་རང་གི་ངང་དུ་གདལ།། Awareness relaxes into itself.
Level 1: Instructions for Meditating on Stillness, Movement, and Awareness
Level 1: Instructions on Pointing Out that All Phenomena Come from Mind
Level 2: Instructions for Meditating on Mind is Emptiness།ཕྱོགས་བཅུ་དུས་གསུམ་སངས་རྒྱས་སྲས་དང་བཅས་པ་དཔང་པོར་གསོལ་ནས་དགེ་བ་གཞན་དོན་དུ་བསྔོ་བ་ནི། With the buddhas of the three times and ten directions, along with their offspring, as your witnesses, dedicate the virtue to the welfare of others: །བདག་གིས་དུས་གསུམ་བསགས་པའི་དགེ་ཚོགས་དང། I dedicate all the virtue I have gathered throughout the three times།རྒྱལ་དང་བྱང་སེམས་འགྲོ་བའི་དགེ་ཀུན་བསྡོམས། Along with the virtue of the victorious ones, the bodhisattvas, and all beings,།ཇི་ལྟར་སངས་རྒྱས་སྲས་བཅས་བསྔོས་པ་བཞིན། Following in the footsteps of the buddhas and their heirs,།མཁའ་ཁྱབ་འགྲོ་ཀུན་གཏན་བདེ་ཐོབ་ཕྱིར་བསྔོ།། To the lasting happiness of all the infinite number of beings. །ཨ་རིའི་བྱར་ཕྱོགས་ཁུལ་གྱི་མཐོ་སློབ་སན་ལྗོནྶ་ནས་གཏེར་སྒར་གྱི་སློབ་ཚོགས་རྣམས་ཀྱི་རེ་བསྐུལ་བཞིན་མི་འགྱུར་རྡོ་རྗེས་ཕྱི་ལོ་༢༠༡༠་ཟླ་བ་༦་པར་མཏཚམས་གྱི་ཐུན་སྐབས་སུ་བྲིས༎ At the request of the students of the Tergar community, Mingyur Dorjé composed this during a meditation session in 2010 at St. John's University in the northern United States.

ཚད་མེད་བཞི།
དྭགས་པོ་བཀའ་བརྒྱུད་སྤྱི་ལ་གསོལ་བ་འདེབས་པ།
མིང་གྱུར་རྡོ་རྗེ་ལ་ཞུས་པ།
མཎྜལ། སངས་རྒྱས་ཆོས་དང་ཚོགས་ཀྱི་མཆོག་རྣམས་ལ། བྱང་ཆུབ་བར་དུ་བདག་ནི་སྐྱབས་སུ་མཆི། བདག་གིས་སྦྱིན་སོགས་བགྱིས་པའི་བསོད་ནམས་ཀྱིས། འགྲོ་ལ་ཕན་ཕྱིར་སངས་རྒྱས་འགྲུབ་པར་ཤོག། སེམས་ཅན་ཐམས་ཅད་བདེ་བ་དང་བདེ་བའི་རྒྱུ་དང་ལྡན་པར་གྱུར་ཅིག། སྡུག་བསྔལ་དང་སྡུག་བསྔལ་གྱི་རྒྱུ་དང་བྲལ་བར་གྱུར་ཅིག། སྡུག་བསྔལ་མེད་པའི་བདེ་བ་དམ་པ་དང་མི་འབྲལ་བར་གྱུར་ཅིག། ཉེ་རིང་ཆགས་སྡང་གཉིས་དང་བྲལ་བའི་བཏང་སྙོམས་ཆེན་པོ་ལ་གནས་པར་གྱུར་ཅིག།
English Cheatsheetརྡོ་རྗེ་འཆང་ཆེན་ཏཻ་ལོ་ནཱ་རོ་དང་། མར་པ་མི་ལ་ཆོས་རྗེ་སྒམ་པོ་པ། དུས་གསུམ་ཤེས་བྱ་ཀུན་མཁྱེན་ཀརྨ་པ། ཆེ་བཞི་ཆུང་བརྒྱད་བརྒྱུད་པ་འཛིན་རྣམས་དང་། འབྲི་སྟག་ཚལ་གསུམ་དཔལ་ལྡན་འབྲུག་པ་སོགས། ཟབ་ལམ་ཕྱག་རྒྱ་ཆེ་ལ་མངའ་བརྙེས་པའི། མཉམ་མེད་འགྲོ་མགོན་དྭགས་པོ་བཀའ་བརྒྱུད་ལ། གསོལ་བ་འདེབས་སོ་བཀའ་བརྒྱུད་བླ་མ་རྣམས། བརྒྱུད་པ་འཛིན་ནོ་རྣམ་ཐར་བྱིན་གྱིས་རློབས། ཞེན་ལོག་སྒོམ་གྱི་རྐང་པར་གསུངས་པ་བཞིན། ཟས་ནོར་ཀུན་ལ་ཆགས་ཞེན་མེད་པ་དང་། ཚེ་འདིར་གདོས་ཐག་ཆོད་པའི་སྒོམ་ཆེན་ལ། རྙེད་བཀུར་ཞེན་པ་མེད་པར་བྱིན་གྱིས་རློབས། མོས་གུས་སྒོམ་གྱི་མགོ་བོར་གསུངས་པ་བཞིན། མན་ངག་གཏེར་སྒོ་འབྱེད་པའི་བླ་མ་ལ། རྒྱུན་དུ་གསོལ་བ་འདེབས་པའི་སྒོམ་ཆེན་ལ། བཅོས་མིན་མོས་གུས་སྐྱེ་བར་བྱིན་གྱིས་རློབས། ཡེངས་མེད་སྒོམ་གྱི་དངོས་གཞིར་གསུངས་པ་བཞིན། གང་ཤར་རྟོག་པའི་ངོ་བོ་སོ་མ་དེ། མ་བཅོས་དེ་ཀར་འཇོག་པའི་སྒོམ་ཆེན་ལ། བསྒོམ་བྱ་བློ་དང་བྲལ་བར་བྱིན་གྱིས་རློབས། རྣམ་རྟོག་ངོ་བོ་ཆོས་སྐུར་གསུངས་པ་བཞིན། ཅི་ཡང་མ་ཡིན་ཅིར་ཡང་འཆར་བ་ལ། མ་འགགས་རོལ་པ་འཆར་བའི་སྒོམ་ཆེན་ལ། འཁོར་འདས་དབྱེར་མེད་རྟོགས་པར་བྱིན་གྱིས་རློབས། སྐྱེ་བ་ཀུན་ཏུ་ཡང་དག་བླ་མ་དང་། འབྲལ་མེད་ཆོས་ཀྱི་དཔལ་ལ་ལོངས་སྤྱོད་ཅིང་། ས་དང་ལམ་གྱི་ཡོན་ཏན་རབ་རྫོགས་ནས། རྡོ་རྗེ་འཆང་གི་གོ་འཕང་མྱུར་ཐོབ་ཤོག།།
English Cheatsheetགཉུག་མའི་གཤིས་ལས་མ་གཡོས་ཆོས་ཀྱི་སྐུ༎ ལྟུན་གྲུབ་རང་སྣང་དག་པ་ལོངས་སྤྱོད་རྫོགས༎ གང་འདུལ་གཟུགས་ཀྱི་སྐུ་བཞེངས་གཏེར་ཆེན་རྫེ༎ མི་འགྱུར་རྡོ་རྫེའི་ཞབས་ལ་གསོལ་བ་འདེབས༎ས་གཞི་སྤོས་ཆུས་བྱུགས་ཤིང་མེ་ཏོག་བཀྲམ། རི་རབ་གླིང་བཞི་ཉི་ཟླས་བརྒྱན་པ་འདི། སངས་རྒྱས་ཞིང་དུ་དམིགས་ཏེ་ཕུལ་བ་ཡིས། འགྲོ་ཀུན་རྣས་དག་ཞིང་ལ་སྤྱོད་པར་ཤོག།

2.-pol/the-heart-sutra.html.description: Tibetan Chant Phonetics Cheatsheet gyagar kedu bhaga wati prajna paramtia hridaaya From India (Sanskrit:) Bhagavati Prajna Paramita Hridayam böe ketu chomden dé ma sherab kyi paroltu chinpe nyingpo bampo chig go (Tibetan:) I bow to Bhagavati (Buddha / the transcendent victor / Blessed One) who from the other side brought the essence (Verses / Sutras) of perfected wisdom diké dag gi töpa du chigna Thus, have I heard chomdendé gyalpo'i khab ja gar püngpo'i rila At one time, the Blessed One dwelt in Rajagriha at Vulture Peak Mountain gelong gi gendün chenpo dang Together with a great sangha of fully ordained monks jangchub sempa'i gendun chenpo dang tab chigtu zhug té And a great sangha of bodhisattvas de'i tsé At that time chomdendé zambo nangwa zhé jawé chökyi nam drang kyi ting ngé dzin la nyompar zhüg so The Blessed One rested in the samadhi of the enumerations of phenomena called “perception of the profound” yang détsé jangchub sempa sempa chenpo pagpa chenrezig wangchug And at the same time noble Avalokiteshvara, the bodhisattva mahasattva sherab kyi paroltu chinpa zabmo'i chöpa nyila nampar ta shing While observing the practice of the profound Perfection of Wisdom, saw in this way: püngpo ngapo dédag la yang rangzhin gyi tongpar nampa ta-o He saw the five Skandhas (aggregates / elements) to be empty of nature dené sangyé kyi tü Then, through the power of the Buddha tsé dang denpa sharibu Venerable Shariputra said to jangchub sempa sempa chenpo pagpa chenrezig wangchug la diké ché méso the noble Avalokiteshvara, the bodhisattva mahasattva: rigkyi bu gang lala sherab kyi paroltu chinpa zambo'i chöpa chepar döpa dé jitar labparja “How should a son or daughter of noble family who wishes to practice the profound Perfection of Wisdom train?” deké ché mépa dang In response jangchub sempa sempa chenpo pagpa chenrezig wangchug The noble Avalokiteshvara, the bodhisattva mahasattva gi tsé dang denpa shara dati bula diké ché mé so said to venerable Shariputra: sharibu rigkyi bu'am rigkyi bumo gang lala sherab kyi paroltu “O Shariputra, sons and daughters of noble family who wish to chinpa zambo'i chöpa chépar döpa dé ditar nampar tawar ja té practice the profound Perfection of Wisdom should see clearly in this way: püngpo ngapo dédag yang rang zhin gyi tongpar nampar yang dagpar jésu ta-o They should see clearly that the five Skandas are empty of nature züg tongpa-o tongpa nyi züg so Form is emptiness; emptiness is form züg lé tongpa nyi zhen mayin tongpa nyi lé kyang züg zhen mayinno Emptiness is none other than form and form is none other than emptiness de zhendu tsorwa dang dushé dang dujé dang nampar shépa nam tongpa-o Just so, feeling, discrimination, formation, and consciousness are empty sharibu détar chötamché tongpa nyidé Thus, Shariputra, all phenomena are emptiness tsen nyi mépa ma kyepa ma gagpa drima mépa They have no characteristics. They do not arise, nor do they cease. They are not impure drima dang drelwa driwa mépa gangwa mépa-o Nor are they pure. They are not diminished, nor are they filled sharibu dé ta wéna tongpa nyila zügmé O Shariputra, thus in emptiness there is no form tsorwa mé dushé mé duché nam mé nampar shépa mé No feeling, no discrimination, no formation, and no consciousness mig mé nawa mé na mé No eyes, no ears, no nose ché mé lu mé yi mé No tongue, no body, and no mind züg mé dra mé dri mé No form, no sound, no smell ro mé reja mé chö mé-do No taste, no object of touch, and no phenomena mig gi kham mépa né yi kyi kham mé No eye element to no mind element yi kyi nampar shepé kham kyi bardu tang médo Up to no mental consciousness element ma rigpa mé ma rigpa zépa mépa mé gashi mé No ignorance and no end of ignorance, up to no old age and death gashi zépé bardu yang mé do And no end of old age and death dé zhiindu dug ngel wa dang kün jungwa dang gogpa dang Just so, there is no suffering, no source, no cessation lam mé teshé mé tobpa mé ma tobpa-ang mé do No path; no wisdom, no attainment, and no nonattainment sharibu, dé tawéna jangchub sempa nam tob'pa mépé chir Therefore, Shariputra, since bodhisattvas have nothing to attain sherab kyi paroltu chinpa la tenching néte They abide by and dwell in the Perfection of Wisdom semla dribpa mépé dragpa médé Since their minds are unobscured, they have no fear chinchi loglé shintu déné nya ngen lédé parchin-to Fully transcending illusion, they reach complete nirvana dusüm du nampar zhügpa'i sangyé tamché kyang All the buddhas throughout the three times sherab kyi paroltu chinpa la téné By relying on the Perfection of Wisdom lana mépa tang dagpar dzogpa'i jangchub tu ngonpar dzogpar sangyé-so Fully awaken to unsurpassed, perfect, complete Enlightenment dé tawéna sherab kyi paroltu chinpa'i ngag Therefore, the mantra of the Perfection of Wisdom rigpa chenpo'i ngag lana mepa'i ngag The mantra of great insight, the unsurpassed mantra mi nyampa dang nyampa'i ngag The mantra equal to that which has no equal dugnygal tamché rabtu zhiwar chépa'i ngag The mantra that completely calms all suffering mi dzünpé na denpar shépar ja té Should be known to be true, for it is not false sherab kyi paroltu chinpa'i ngag mé pa The Perfection of Wisdom mantra is spoken as follows: TEYATA OM GATÉ GATÉ PARAGATÉ PARASAMGATÉ BODHI SOHA Gone, gone, gone all the way, everyone gone to the other shore, hail Enlightenment sharibu jangchub sempa sempa chenpo Shariputra, a bodhisattva mahasattva detar sherab kyi paroltu chinpa zabmo la labpar ja-o Should practice the profound Perfection of Wisdom in this way” déné chomdendé tingédzin délé zhengté The Blessed One then arose from his samadhi jangchub sempa sempa chenpo pagpa chenrezig wangchug And said to noble Avalokiteshvara, the bodhisattva mahasattva la lekso zhéjawa ghiné lekso lekso rigkyi bu dé dezhinno rigkyi bu dé dézhin té “Good, good, child of noble family; thus it is, child of noble family; thus it is jitar chekyi tenpa zhintu sherab kyi paroltu chinpa zambo la chépar jaté The profound Perfection of Wisdom should be practiced just as you have taught dézhin shegpa nam kyang jésu yirang ngo And all the tatagatas (buddhas) will rejoice” chondendé kyi déké chéka tsélné When the Blessed One said this tsedang denpa shara dati budang jangchub sempa chenrezig wangchug dang Venerable Shariputra and noble Avalokiteshvara, the bodhisattva mahasattva tamché dang denpa'i khor dé dang Along with the entire retinue and lha dang mi dang lhamayin dang drizar chépé jigten yi-rang-té The world with its gods, humans, asuras (demi-gods), and gandharvas (celestial spirits) rejoiced chomdendé kyi süngpa la ngönpar tö do And praised the words of the Blessed One ༈ རྒྱ་གར་སྐད་དུ། In the language of India:བྷ་ག་བ་ཏི་པྲཛྙཱ་པཱ་ར་མི་ཏཱ་ཧྲི་ད་ཡ། Bhagavatī prajñāpāramitā hṛdayaབོད་སྐད་དུ། བཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས་མ་ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པའི་སྙིང་པོ བམ་པོ་གཅིག་གོ༎ In the language of Tibet: I bow to Bhagavati (Buddha / the transcendent victor / Blessed One) who from the other side brought the essence (Verses / Sutras) of perfected wisdomའདི་སྐད་བདག་གིས་ཐོས་པ་དུས་གཅིག་ན། Thus have I heard:བཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས་རྒྱལ་པོའི་ཁབ་བྱ་རྒོད་ཕུང་པོའི་རི་ལ་དགེ་སློང་གི་དགེ་འདུན་ཆེན་པོ་དང༌། At one time the Blessed One was dwelling in Rājgṛha at Vulture Peak mountain, together with a great community ofབྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའི་དགེ་འདུན་ཆེན་པོ་དང་ཐབས་གཅིག་ཏུ་བཞུགས་ཏེ། monks and a great community of bodhisattvas.དེའི་ཚེ་བཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས་ཟབ་མོ་སྣང་བ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་ཆོས་ཀྱི་རྣམ་གྲངས་ཀྱི་ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་ལ་སྙོམས་པར་ཞུགས་སོ།། At that time, the Blessed One entered an absorption on categories of phenomena called ‘perception of the profound’.ཡང་དེའི་ཚེ་བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་སེམས་དཔའ་ཆེན་པོ་འཕགས་པ་སྤྱན་རས་གཟིགས་དབང་ཕྱུག་ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པ་ཟབ་མོ་སྤྱོད་པ་ཉིད་ལ་རྣམ་པར་བལྟ་ཞིང་། At the same time, noble Avalokiteśvara, the bodhisattva and great being, beheld the practice of the profound perfection of wisdom,ཕུང་པོ་ལྔ་པོ་དེ་དག་ལ་ཡང་རང་བཞིན་གྱིས་སྟོང་པར་རྣམ་པར་བལྟའོ།། And saw that the five aggregates are empty of nature.དེ་ནས་སངས་རྒྱས་ཀྱི་མཐུས། Then, through the Buddha's power,ཚེ་དང་ལྡན་པ་ཤཱ་རིའི་བུས་བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་སེམས་དཔའ་ཆེན་པོ་འཕགས་པ་སྤྱན་རས་གཟིགས་དབང་ཕྱུག་ལ་འདི་སྐད་ཅེས་སྨྲས་སོ།། Venerable Śāriputra said to noble Avalokiteśvara, the bodhisattva and great being:རིགས་ཀྱི་བུ་གང་ལ་ལ་ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པ་ཟབ་མོ་སྤྱོད་པ་སྤྱད་པར་འདོད་པ་དེས་ཇི་ལྟར་བསླབ་པར་བྱ། “How should a child of noble family who wishes to practise the profound perfection of wisdom train?”དེ་སྐད་ཅེས་སྨྲས་པ་དང༌། བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་སེམས་དཔའ་ཆེན་པོ་འཕགས་པ་སྤྱན་རས་གཟིགས་དབང་ཕྱུག་གིས་ཚེ་དང་ལྡན་པ་ཤཱ་ར་དྭ་ཏིའི་བུ་ལ་འདི་སྐད་ཅེས་སྨྲས་སོ།། This is what he said, and the noble Avalokiteśvara, the bodhisattva and great being, replied to venerable Śāriputra as follows:ཤཱ་རིའི་བུ་རིགས་ཀྱི་བུ་འམ་རིགས་ཀྱི་བུ་མོ་གང་ལ་ལ་ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པ་ཟབ་མོ་སྤྱོད་པ་སྤྱད་པར་འདོད་པ་དེས་འདི་ལྟར་རྣམ་པར་བལྟ་བར་བྱ་སྟེ། “O Śāriputra, a son of noble family or daughter of noble family who wishes to practise the profound perfection of wisdom should regard things in this way:ཕུང་པོ་ལྔ་པོ་དེ་དག་ཀྱང་རང་བཞིན་གྱིས་སྟོང་པར་རྣམ་པར་ཡང་དག་པར་རྗེས་སུ་བལྟའོ།། They should see the five aggregates to be empty of nature.གཟུགས་སྟོང་པའོ། །སྟོང་པ་ཉིད་ཀྱང་གཟུགས་སོ།། Form is empty; emptiness is form;གཟུགས་ལས་སྟོང་པ་ཉིད་གཞན་མ་ཡིན་ནོ།། Emptiness is not other than form;སྟོང་པ་ཉིད་ལས་ཀྱང་གཟུགས་གཞན་མ་ཡིན་ནོ།། Form is not other than emptiness.དེ་བཞིན་དུ་ཚོར་བ་དང༌། འདུ་ཤེས་དང༌། In the same way, sensation, recognition,འདུ་བྱེད་དང༌། རྣམ་པར་ཤེས་པ་རྣམས་སྟོང་པའོ།། Conditioning factors and consciousness are emptiness.ཤཱ་རིའི་བུ་དེ་ལྟ་བས་ན་ཆོས་ཐམས་ཅད་སྟོང་པ་ཉིད་དེ། Therefore, Śāriputra, all dharmas are emptiness.མཚན་ཉིད་མེད་པ། མ་སྐྱེས་པ། མ་འགགས་པ། They are without characteristics; they are unarisen and unceasing;དྲི་མ་མེད་པ། དྲི་མ་དང་བྲལ་བ་མེད་པ། They are not tainted and not untainted;བྲི་བ་མེད་པ། གང་བ་མེད་པའོ།། They are not deficient and not complete.ཤཱ་རིའི་བུ་དེ་ལྟ་བས་ན་སྟོང་པ་ཉིད་ལ་གཟུགས་མེད། Therefore, Śāriputra, in emptiness, there is no form,ཚོར་བ་མེད། འདུ་ཤེས་མེད། འདུ་བྱེད་རྣམས་མེད། རྣམ་པར་ཤེས་པ་མེད། No sensation, no recognition, no conditioning factors, no consciousness;མིག་མེད། རྣ་བ་མེད། སྣ་མེད། ལྕེ་མེད། ལུས་མེད། ཡིད་མེད། No eye, no ear, no nose, no tongue, no body, no mind;གཟུགས་མེད། སྒྲ་མེད། དྲི་མེད། རོ་མེད། རེག་བྱ་མེད། ཆོས་མེད་དོ།། No visible form, no sound, no odour, no taste, no texture, and no mental objects;མིག་གི་ཁམས་མེད་པ་ནས་ཡིད་ཀྱི་ཁམས་མེད། There is no eye element up to no mind element;ཡིད་ཀྱི་རྣམ་པར་ཤེས་པའི་ཁམས་ཀྱི་བར་དུ་ཡང་མེད་དོ།། And as far as no mental consciousness element;མ་རིག་པ་མེད། མ་རིག་པ་ཟད་པ་མེད་པ་ནས་རྒ་ཤི་མེད། There is no ignorance, no extinction of ignorance up to no old age and death,རྒ་ཤི་ཟད་པའི་བར་དུ་ཡང་མེད་དོ།། No extinction of old age and death;སྡུག་བསྔལ་བ་དང༌། ཀུན་འབྱུང་བ་དང༌། No suffering, no origin,འགོག་པ་དང༌། ལམ་མེད། ཡེ་ཤེས་མེད། ཐོབ་པ་མེད། No cessation, no path, no wisdom, no attainment,མ་ཐོབ་པ་ཡང་མེད་དོ།། And no non-attainment.ཤཱ་རིའི་བུ་དེ་ལྟ་བས་ན་བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་རྣམས་ཐོབ་པ་མེད་པའི་ཕྱིར། Therefore, Śāriputra, since bodhisattvas have no attainment,ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པ་ལ་བརྟེན་ཅིང་གནས་ཏེ། They rely on and abide by the perfection of wisdom.སེམས་ལ་སྒྲིབ་པ་མེད་པས་སྐྲག་པ་མེད་དེ། Since their minds are unobscured, they have no fear.ཕྱིན་ཅི་ལོག་ལས་ཤིན་ཏུ་འདས་ནས་མྱ་ངན་ལས་འདས་པའི་མཐར་ཕྱིན་ཏོ།། They completely transcend error and reach the ultimate nirvāṇa.དུས་གསུམ་དུ་རྣམ་པར་བཞུགས་པའི་སངས་རྒྱས་ཐམས་ཅད་ཀྱང་ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པ་ལ་བརྟེན་ནས། All the buddhas throughout the three timesབླ་ན་མེད་པ་ཡང་དག་པར་རྫོགས་པའི་བྱང་ཆུབ་ཏུ་མངོན་པར་རྫོགས་པར་སངས་རྒྱས་སོ།། Fully awaken to unsurpassable, true, complete enlightenment by means of the perfection of wisdom.དེ་ལྟ་བས་ན་ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པའི་སྔགས། Therefore, the mantra of the perfection of wisdom—རིག་པ་ཆེན་པོའི་སྔགས། བླ་ན་མེད་པའི་སྔགས། The mantra of great insight, the unsurpassed mantra,མི་མཉམ་པ་དང་མཉམ་པའི་སྔགས། སྡུག་བསྔལ་ཐམས་ཅད་རབ་ཏུ་ཞི་བར་བྱེད་པའི་སྔགས། The mantra that equals the unequalled, the mantra that pacifies all suffering—མི་བརྫུན་པས་ན་བདེན་པར་ཤེས་པར་བྱ་སྟེ། Is not false and should be understood as true.ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པའི་སྔགས་སྨྲས་པ། The mantra of the perfection of wisdom is proclaimed as follows:ཏདྱ་ཐཱ། ཨོཾ་ག་ཏེ་ག་ཏེ་པཱ་ར་ག་ཏེ། པཱ་ར་སཾ་ག་ཏེ། བོ་དྷི་སྭཱ་ཧཱ། Gone, gone, gone all the way, everyone gone to the other shore, hail Enlightenmentཤཱ་རིའི་བུ་བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་སེམས་དཔའ་ཆེན་པོས་དེ་ལྟར་ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པ་ཟབ་མོ་ལ་བསླབ་པར་བྱའོ།། Śāriputra, a bodhisattva and great being should train in the profound perfection of wisdom in this way.”དེ་ནས་བཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས་ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་དེ་ལས་བཞེངས་ཏེ། Thereupon, the Blessed One arose from that absorptionབྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་སེམས་དཔའ་ཆེན་པོ་འཕགས་པ་སྤྱན་རས་གཟིགས་དབང་ཕྱུག་ལ་ལེགས་སོ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་བྱིན་ནས། And commended Avalokiteśvara, the bodhisattva and great being:ལེགས་སོ་ལེགས་སོ། །རིགས་ཀྱི་བུ་དེ་དེ་བཞིན་ནོ། །རིགས་ཀྱི་བུ་དེ་དེ་བཞིན་ཏེ། “Excellent, excellent, O son of noble family, that is how it is. That is just how it is.ཇི་ལྟར་ཁྱོད་ཀྱིས་བསྟན་པ་དེ་བཞིན་དུ་ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པ་ཟབ་མོ་ལ་སྤྱད་པར་བྱ་སྟེ། One should practise the profound perfection of wisdom just as you have taughtདེ་བཞིན་གཤེགས་པ་རྣམས་ཀྱང་རྗེས་སུ་ཡི་རང་ངོ་།། And then even the tathāgatas will rejoice.”བཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས་ཀྱིས་དེ་སྐད་ཅེས་བཀའ་སྩལ་ནས། When the Blessed One had said this,ཚེ་དང་ལྡན་པ་ཤཱ་རིའི་བུ་དང༌། Venerable Śāriputra, andབྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་སེམས་དཔའ་ཆེན་པོ་འཕགས་པ་སྤྱན་རས་གཟིགས་དབང་ཕྱུག་དང༌། Noble Avalokiteśvara, the bodhisattva and great being,ཐམས་ཅད་དང་ལྡན་པའི་འཁོར་དེ་དག་དང༌། ལྷ་དང༌། མི་དང༌། Together with the whole assembly and the world of gods, human beings,ལྷ་མ་ཡིན་དང༌། དྲི་ཟར་བཅས་པའི་འཇིག་རྟེན་ཡི་རངས་ཏེ། Asuras and gandharvas rejoiced and praisedབཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས་ཀྱིས་གསུངས་པ་ལ་མངོན་པར་བསྟོད་དོ།། The speech of the Blessed One.བཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས་མ་ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པའི་སྙིང་པོ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོའི་མདོ་རྫོགས་སོ།།།། Thus concludes the Mahāyāna Sūtra of the Blessed Mother, the Heart of the Transcendent Perfection of Wisdom.← Homepage | Nectar of the Path →

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/c.title: Common Pitfalls In Retreat
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/c.description: The easiest mistakes are kind of like being lazy. We have this habit, the habit of not doing retreat, and when you do retreat, this is something new and a big change for you. To build up this new habit is not so easy. Say you are doing four sessions per day, it is not so easy.In the beginning, you might have a lot of enthusiasm, but after some time you will lose it. Then, when you do retreat you suddenly go off track, you grab your phone, read books, and maybe nowadays surfing on your phone or watch television. In the ancient times, they were painting thangkas or making clothes. So these things easily come in retreat, it is an easy mistake to make. Therefore, you need to stay with a structure. If the sessions are too long, you have to make them shorter and do more of them.There are other mistakes like being attached to meditation experiences. When you do retreat, your meditation experience becomes better and better. You will have more clarity and bliss, feeling blissful, peaceful, and joyful — all of these things — and experience a non-conceptual state of mind. You might feel like, "OK. Now I have achieved a high level of realization." or you think, "From now on, I will have no problems with negative emotions or monkey mind (or whatever you want to call it). I am completely free and liberated." These are attachments. You might be stuck in these meditation experiences, being attached to these meditation experiences. This is another easy mistake to make.Sometimes, you even know that you should not get attached to the meditation experience, but you cannot really help it. It is not so easy. That is OK. One important thing is to make room for mistakes. When you do retreat, you will not meditate in the four sessions from beginning to end, it is impossible. A lot of things will happen: you will get lost, the quality will not be good, after some time you will not know what you are doing, and then the waterfall experience with these negative emotions comes.When I was young and did retreat I one time did a retreat here — now I am in Osel Ling monastery — I wanted to do retreat for one week in Osel Ling monastery and at that time my father was in the Ka Nying monastery, near the big stupa in Nepal, in the Eastern part of Kathmandu, and I was here in the Western part of Kathmandu. So, I was with my father in the Eastern part of Kathmandu, and I told my father that I was going to do retreat for one week and I came here to Osel Ling monastery. In the beginning, my meditation experience was so wonderful. I was very clear, I was so happy and joyful, and I felt like, "Finally! I am in the right place, with the right circumstances, under the right situation." everything was just right. Then, on day three this bliss, joy, and whatever else felt right was completely gone, the wonderful experiences that I expected were completely gone. Then my mind became very dry and I could not get a taste of meditation. It became dry and I did not know what I was doing. My mind became foggy and as soon as I started my meditation sessions it became like this (Mingyur Rinpoche pretends to fall asleep). That one was quite bad so when I had finished the one week I felt so happy (Mingyur Rinpoche laughs). So that retreat did not go very well.Some days your retreat might not go so well either. Even if your retreat does not go so well, try your best, and it is OK to fail. Failing is the mother of success. Whatever we do, in the beginning, we might fail. When you look at very successful people, they are the ones that fail the most in the beginning. They fail more because they try more. "This does not work. That does not work. Here it does not work." but in the end, when one thing works well, they become very successful. It is the same thing with retreat.Do not be attached to meditation experiences. Do not expect your retreat to be wonderful and fantastic. Try to stay with a structure without mixing it up too much, but within the meditation sessions, you can change (method) from time to time. That is OK. No problem.These are all easy mistakes to do on retreat, and many people do make these kinds of mistakes, and after that, they feel discouraged. Some of this is normal, it is part of the waterfall experience. If you do retreat, sometimes it might be like that. Instead of being discouraged, you have to appreciate it, "Wow! Now my mind has become crazier than before and I think more than before. How nice! My mind has become very dull. How nice!" You can appreciate it the other way around. Then it will give you a lot of inspiration and the next retreat will be better.

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/e.title: Energy Movement
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/e.description:
Sometimes, some people when they meditate, after some time they will have this energy movement. Some people, when they meditate in a very tight way or do meditation intensively, afterward the energy movement comes. Some people, because of what we call, "Prana, bindu, nadi," in the body; prana, bindu, nadi means the channels, energy, and the cells in the body. You have energy movement. Normally, 10% of the people have this energy movement.What is energy movement? Energy movement is, actually, when you meditate your body is transforming. Your cells, energy in the body, everything is transforming. It is transforming from negative to positive, and from positive to wisdom. The transformation from positive to wisdom only comes after the direct realization of your true nature, the nature of mind. But, the normal transformation from impure to pure comes with any meditation technique. If you do any meditation that is related to awareness, it will transform. For some people, in the transition of this transformation, they will have this energy movement.Energy movement has four things: first is the five sensory perceptions, the second is a special sense in the mind, the third is emotions going up and down, and the fourth is physical body sensations, these are the four thingsMaybe I will tell you about the last one, the fourth, about physical sensations. Some people feel warmth or heat on the top of their head. They feel like something is moving or opening here, and sometimes there are some kind of energy that moves at the center of your head. For some people, there is a sense of tingling from the bottom of the spine moving upward, like an electric movement. Like a sensation of tingling or electrical movement. Some people feel heat around their stomach. They feel warmth and heat coming from the stomach. Some people feel a pressure in the forehead, throat, and heart-center. They feel some pressure or heat or something like that. Some people even have movements taking place inside of their bodies. It is kind of like a vibration inside the body that is shaking. Some people feel like the energy comes and shoots to the top of their head. Sometimes it feels like the energy comes and then get stuck in the throat, heart-center, or the forehead, it cannot flow. Sometimes you want to cry, without a reason. Just tears are coming. Sometimes, if people have very strong energy movements, they do different mudras, dance, shake, or something like that. These are the energy movements related to physical signs.Then we have the five sensory perceptions. What are the five sensory perceptions? The eyes, ears, nose, tongue, etc. From the eyes, you can sometimes see colors, sparks, and bindus. Or some people they see visions — visions of enlightened beings, visions of their teacher, or sometimes visions of ghosts, demons, and maras. They see good, bad, and neutral things.Next is sound. You hear a particular sound that nobody else around hears. Your friends do not hear it but you do. People around you do not hear the sound but you hear it. Sometimes, that sound could be a mantra, or it could be a teaching, an enlightened being or a buddha teaching you, your teacher giving you special messages, or sometimes there are messages coming from demons or ghosts, it looks like someone is spying on you, watching you, telling you things, like a guide. It could be something like that.Next is smell. You smell something which your friends cannot smell. Not so many people have this taste and smell thing.Sometimes it is almost like you feel something tactile. It feels like there is a presence of someone, maybe an enlightened being or demon nearby, and it is almost like you feel that person and you almost see and hear it sometimes.Sometimes the five sensory perceptions come together. That is also possible. These are the five sensory perceptionsThe next is this special sense. One has a sense of energy. "This place has positive energy. This place has negative energy. This person has positive energy. I am receiving positive energy from this person. I am receiving negative energy from that person. Oh. I am receiving positive energy from my teacher. My teacher is there with me, right next to me. I have a special connection with my teacher. We are communicating in different ways. Today my teacher came and talked to me." or something like that. It is like one can sense it, almost. Maybe you do not see it, but you sense it. Sometimes you can see it, but you do not sense it. Sometimes both of these are together. It also depends on the personality having this sense of energy. In some places you can sense good energy, in other places, there is bad energy. All of this belongs to the sense of energy.The last one is that one's emotions go up and down. Sometimes you feel blissful, joyful, and clear. You are so happy and then you enter a special state of mind and then suddenly this happiness or joyful experience is completely gone. You can also have a lot of anger, or sometimes strong desire, anxiety, or different kind of emotions that come. So, the emotions go up and down.These are the four things. Among these four things, two are real and two are not real. What are the real ones? The physical signs, like feeling heat here (Mingyur Rinpoche points to the top of his head) or it feels like there is an opening, with this there is something really happening in your body, so that one is real. The second one is when the emotions are going up and down. Having emotional ups and downs is real because you have emotions and you are feeling emotions. But two things are not real. This five sensory perception is not real. Seeing a buddha or a demon, hearing wonderful enlightened messages or hearing bad messages from demons or maras are not real. Do not get attached to this. The same goes for smells, tastes, and all these things. The sense of energy is also not real. Whatever you are feeling, if you are receiving bad energy or receiving good energy is not real.Now, what do you have to do? You have to view it as watching television — watching 3D television. When you go to a big cinema and watches 3D you wear glasses, right? And you see everything as real and there are sounds and smells and all these things. So, treat these experiences similar to watching television. Do not believe in these things. Some people do not know that this is energy movement and they get attached to those messages. When you receive positive visions and messages you think, "Aha! I am enlightened. Finally, something is happening with me. Ha! I have visions of these teachers and buddhas and now I am receiving teachings every day, and the message says, 'You are the most important person in this world! You came to this world to benefit others.'" Do not believe in these things. Do not be attached to that.Sometimes these messages turn into rough or bad things, like ghosts harming you, "Oh! You will have big obstacles next time." It is like someone is watching and spying on you and giving you obstacles and bad energies, or something like that. This is also not real. Do not be attached to that. Do not think that you are special and do not think that you are crazy. Some people think, "I have become crazy." and some people think, "I am enlightened."
You are not enlighted.
You are not crazy.
It is just energy movement.
Do not be attached to that. Treat it just like you are watching television, do physical exercise sometimes, this is really important, and drink a lot of water. And if you know that this is energy movement, and you know that this is not real but these images, voices, or energy movements still come — it will not disappear right away — but every time you tell yourself, "This is just energy movement. I am not crazy. I am not enlightened. It is just energy movement." Energy movement is not bad, actually. It is the sign of something, the sign of transformation. But if you get attached to it, if you think it is real, then that is the problem.If you move too much sometimes, let us say that you put both of your hands together and put on the top of your head, it helps sometimes. Also, do not meditate too long. You have to break it up — short times many times, short times many times. Sometimes, you can meditate while standing up or while walking. Do walking and standing meditation. These are very good. If you do not know about energy movement and you have been attached to energy movements for a long time, and you cannot get away from the energy movements, then maybe do not meditate for one month of half a month. Stop meditating and do some physical exercise. Then you can again begin to meditate a little bit, short times, many times. Then it will be fineThis is very important to know. Many people are confused about this, and they do not know that this is energy movement. It is very important to recognize this energy movement and to not be attached to these experiences.

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/h.title: How To Practice In Retreat, Summary Of Key Points
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/h.description:
The Tibetan word for retreat is "tsam" and means, "boundary".
The reason we create a boundary is to minimize negative actions and kleshas, and get more time for virtuous activities.
Negative emotions continue due to three causes: Ego-clinging - internal cause
The object is nearby - environmental cause
Motivational factor - relationship between above causes Without transforming yourself, you cannot transform the world.
If you embody what you say, then even if you just say one word, the influence becomes very strong and will benefit others. The best is to find balance between retreat and daily practice — then they will really support each other.
In the beginning, it is very important to do short, high quality retreats.
You can use the same schedule for retreats of different lengths.
Stick to the meditation structure, within that structure, change the meditation methods.
Alternating meditation methods supports the methods themselves.
Keep the sessions in retreat between 1-3 hours each.
If you do retreat at home, create a supportive environment.
Every month, try to do one weekend retreat.
Doing retreat is a very precious and valuable thing to do in the world.
Retreat is not an escape, but rather a way to benefit others. The waterfall experience is a good sign that your meditation is progressing.
The waterfall experience will make it look like your negative emotions increase, but suddenly it will change, you will feel very happy — this is a good sign.
Meditation experience going up and down are both good: Down experiences are good for realization
Up experiences are good for inspiration The signs of meditation are: Equanimity and inner peace
Awareness
Kindness and Compassion
Wisdom Since meditation experience goes up and down, do not look for improvements day-by-day but focus on the long-term.
Realization develops little by little, so you cannot track it day-by-day.
A warning sign is becoming attached to experiences; they then turn into a boost for your ego.
If the ego becomes stronger and you become more arrogant, that means you are off track.
Experience always changes, but realization is enduring.
Appreciate even tiny transformations that take place in retreat.
Let go of expectations, focus on the motivation, and do not give up.
Example: Cow Dung on the Wall
In India, people often dry cow dung on the walls of their home and use the dried cow dung for cooking fires. This is used as an example for the waterfall experience. When the cow dung has dried it does not look so bad and it does not smell much. But if you put water onto it in an effort to clean it off the wall, it becomes very dirty and smells really bad. Similarly, we may not notice our thoughts and emotions as much when we are not paying attention, but when we begin to meditate we begin to see them more clearly.Example: Fish in a Muddy River
If a river becomes muddy, you cannot see the fish in the river. But when the river becomes clean and pure again, you can see the fish in the river. This does not mean that the river gets more fish, you are simply just able to see them because the water is clean. Similarly, before practicing meditation you were one with your thoughts and emotions and therefore could not see them. Now, however, you begin to recognize your thoughts and emotions and can see them because your mind has become more calm and peaceful.Example: Traveling from Eastern to Central Tibet
In old Tibet, if you wanted to travel from eastern Tibet to central Tibet you had to walk through the mountains. Whether you were going up or down the mountain, you were continuously getting closer to your destination. Similarly, for a meditator, experience goes up and down and both the ups and downs of experience bring you closer to the goal.

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/i.title: Inspiration And Discouragement
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/i.description:
Many Westerners are inspired by the life story of Milarepa, but sometimes it turns into discouragement because we might think that we are not good enough, that we do not have a strong, determined mind, like Milarepa, or that we do not have enough wisdom or faith.How should we deal with this feeling — when Westerners cannot really do or follow their teacher's example or how the great lineage masters did it in the past?I think Milarepa said:Quote
Those of my followers in the future, you might think all this that I did — the training, retreats, and various hardships, like spending many, many years in the mountains and going through all these hardships — this is impossible.
— Milarepa
Some people think, “Normal people cannot do that, because Milarepa was a special emanation of the Buddha.” or something like that. "We have to take care of our families, and we have this everyday life so we cannot achieve liberation." Some people think like that. Milarepa said:Quote
The most important thing is our mind. For a mind that is really focused on meditation and focused on the dharma, the outside circumstances do not matter much.
— Milarepa
Milarepa said that there are four possibilities: (1) Doing retreat in the mountains, but the mind is in the city. So, your mind is busy and involved in aversion and attachment and all these things, but the body is in the mountains; (2) the body is in the city or town but the mind is in the mountains; (3) both together — the body is in the mountains and the mind is in the mountains; (4) neither — both the body and the mind are not in the mountains. These are the four possibilities.One possibility is that the body is in the city, but the mind is in the mountains. What is the meaning of the mind being in the mountains? The meaning is that you are practicing meditation in everyday life. Sometimes we call this, "Enlightened without cutting the hair." The meaning is that you do not have to become a monk or nun, and you do not have to go to a cave. You do everything, just like in a normal life, but you need to practice.How to practice in the beginning? You have to practice short times many times, little by little. You need to change your habits, in the beginning. When it comes to changing habits, we cannot change huge habits, right away. If a train goes forward very fast and you would like to change the direction, first, you need to slow down, right? You need to slow down and you change little by little. You cannot change right away, like this (Mingyur Rinpoche turns his hand 180 degrees.) You change little by little, and then you can change the whole habit. It is similar to that.We have very strong habits from everyday life, the monkey mind is continuous, so we cannot change this experience right away. If you have the opportunity to go to the mountains and at the same time the mind is in the mountains, this is wonderful. But if you cannot do that, there are still opportunities. You can still get liberated. Especially, when we really consider transformation, sometimes when there are good qualities, you can transform even within a short time. Sometimes we say:
"Seven days of retreat with very good quality
Is equal to maybe one year of retreat."
Sometimes it can become like that. I have seen that. Sometimes people do retreat and the mind is all over the world and they do not really know or they are not really engaged, so even if they finish long-term retreat, they have not changed much. But some people went to retreat for one week, and after one week they completely changed. So the quality matters. Time does not really matter, and the environment does not really matter.For me, when I was in retreat, for the first few months I was lazy and busy. Although my body was in retreat — my body was in the mountains — but my mind was not in the mountains. My mind was together with my panic and laziness and went around the world (Mingyur Rinpoche laughs.) During these few months, I did not improve much. But later I really tried to put in an effort, only for a few days, and these few days really changed my life. I had panic, so I really practiced with the panic, I really put my heart into the practice, and these few days really helped.Do not worry too much about if you do not have the opportunity to go to the mountains. You cannot do it like Milarepa, but you can do it in a different way. You can make your home a mountain. You can make your city the mountain. You will have the opportunity to get liberated in your lifetime. To become Buddha within one lifetime might be quite difficult, be honest, but what we call, "direct realization" (is possible.) You can achieve direct realization in one life, which is wonderful, and many people these days are achieving that direct realization in one life. I have seen in my village, in Nubri, old grandpas and grandmas, their faces filled with a smile, and they are using prayer wheels (Mingyur Rinpoche pretends using a prayer wheel.) They say:
"If I die tomorrow, that is OK.
If I live long, that is OK."
They are full of joy. That is possible.

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/m.title: My Inspirations
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/m.description: The source of inspiration for doing my retreat began with Milarepa's life story. When I was young, my mom would do bedtime reading. In my hometown — I was born in the northern parts of Nepal, right in the middle of the Himalayan mountains, our culture, lifestyle, and everything else, was just like in Tibet — we had an ancient lifestyle. For lunch, we would have a lot of food, but our dinner would normally be light — mostly we had soup. At dinner­time, our family got together around the fire — we made a fire which we sat around — most of the time it was my grandpa, grandma, mom, and me, and we all sat around the fire and we would drink the soup. Having finished the soup, my grandpa went to meditate, and my grandma, me, and mom were together. My grandma did not know how to read and I also did not know how to read at that time, so it was only my mom who knew how to read. She would read different books. Most of the time, she read Milarepa's life story — slowly, slowly. Sometimes, when Milarepa was facing problems, my grandma cried, then I cried, and in the end my mom cried — we cried, and cried. Then, we cleaned our eyes and began to read again — it was so nice! I really liked Milarepa's life style; to practice, to do retreat in the mountains — in the caves — I liked that.Later on, I learned meditation from my father. My father also did a lot of retreat. He did retreat for three years in Tibet. He put himself in retreat and he sealed the door. The toilet and everything was inside. There was only a small window from which he received the food. He did like this for three years.My other teacher, Saljay Rinpoche, did three­year retreat a few times. Nyoshul Khen Rinpoche, another teacher of mine, did formal retreat first, in Tibet, and later on he came to India and did wandering retreat. He went from place to place. Sometimes he mixed with the sadhus. His story is fantastic! It has really been an inspiration to me.When I was young, I grew up with these great masters around me. Although I had these panic attacks and it was miserable, I was inspired by the people around me. When I was thirteen years old I thought, "I should do retreat." I was having these panic attacks, and these panic attacks was, normally what I call, "following me like a shadow." When I was nine I learned to meditate. I did my daily practice and I did not do retreat until I was thirteen — before that I never did retreat. When I did my daily practice, it sometimes helped, sometimes not, it was on and off. But sometimes I even forgot to do daily practice. It was really difficult to keep it up continuously, so when I was thirteen I thought, "I am going to go to do retreat for three years. This will be good for me. My laziness will not be there, so I can be free of my panic."Then I went to retreat. But, at first, my panic got worse, because my laziness followed me into retreat. So, I was in the gym, but I was not doing any exercise. (Laughs.) Then, my panic got worse. Later on, I really tried my best to follow the retreat schedule. When I followed the retreat schedule, I really applied my meditation with the panic. I accepted my panic and continued to do so. Then, later on my panic my best friend and my teacher. I think that was because of my retreat. It really helped me. It changed my life. Retreat changed my life.After that, I have been quite happy. I am not saying I did not have any panic again, I did, but even when I had panic, it was not a panic attack, but sometimes you feel fear, everybody feels fear, right? When I felt panic, I remembered my meditation practice, and it really helped me. If I would not have done retreat, perhaps I may not have completely transformed like that. So, for me, retreat is really important. That has impacted my life. It completely changed my life. Therefore, sometimes I recommend people to do retreat; but, to do retreat with good quality is really important. Even if you do daily practice for one hour, trying to fully practice for one hour, will really make a change and be of benefit.Nowadays, some people do retreat for a long time, but they do not know how to gradually develop the experience of retreat, so they push it — just like I did. I suddenly went into retreat, and my laziness came back in the retreat, and my panic became worse.Therefore, if you do a good quality retreat — even for one week — it may change your entire life experience. Therefore, it has been of real impact to me, and I hope it will be for you to. Also, do not worry if you cannot do long retreats, but try to do good quality retreats — even for two days — and it may change your life.

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/r.title: Retreat Is Not An Escape
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/r.description: How can we make sure that doing retreat will be of benefit to others rather than turning into an escape?That really depends on your motivation. If your motivation is to transform yourself and then help others, give a positive influence to your friends, family, society, world, etc., if you have that kind of motivation, retreat is really meaningful. If you really want to transform the world, first you need to transform yourself. Without transforming yourself, you cannot transform the world.When we look at the history of the world, the dictators did not want to transform themselves, they wanted to transform the world, they wanted to change the world, they wanted to change other, therefore, there have been wars in the past. They wanted to control everything.The first time I went abroad, before the plane took off, I saw a short presentation, and they said that before you have put the oxygen mask on yourself do not help others. First, help yourself, put on your oxygen mask, and then help others. "Why is that?" I thought. "Why is this important?" So, I asked some other people, and they said, "If you try to put on the oxygen mask on others first, who knows, you might neither help yourself nor others? Because you might run out of breath before having helped others. So, in the end, both lose. First, you help yourself, and then you have the energy to help others." I thought this was a really good example.If we really want to have a deeper effect on the world, then we really need to try to transform deep within ourselves. If you transform, you may influence, let us say, two people. First one person, then two persons. If you transform one or two people, that can help another one or two people. That one or two people can help others, so in the end, we can transform the world. Why? Because we are all part of ripples. In the beginning, the ripples are tiny, not big, but then, as the wave goes, it becomes bigger and bigger and bigger. With anything unique, anything special, the influence becomes very big.The first time I went to America, they used American slang. In America, many people were using this slang, but in Canada, no one knew about this slang. Six months later, I went to Canada again and everybody was using this slang! Then I asked them, "Where did you get this slang from?" It was not on television, it was not on the news, it was not on some particular advertisement. They said it was, "the word of mouth." Because it was unique and something special it spread out a lot. If you really transform yourself, if you yourself becomes unique and genuine, that becomes very powerful and it will benefit others.In Tibet, we say, "Between saying a hundred things and doing one, doing one is more powerful than saying a hundred things." The meaning is that if you tell everyone, "You should do this, you should do that..." but you yourself do the opposite, you do not do what you say, then whatever you say do not have any value. It will not really benefit others. But if you really do it. If you are embodying whatever you are saying, then even if you say just one word, the influence becomes very strong and will benefit others. Therefore, retreat is not an escape. Actually, if you know, retreat is very important, valuable, and it is really the way to benefit othersFor example, Milarepa — the great Tibetan saint. He is similar to a saint, like a great Indian mahasiddha. For me, Milarepa is my hero. When I was young, my mom, me, and my grandma all got together around the fire and we drank soup. After finishing the soup, my mom read books about the life of Milarepa. My grandma liked the Tibetan folktales, and I liked Milarepa, so sometimes we argued a little bit. My mom sometimes read the folktales and stories, and sometimes she read the Milarepa’s life story. In the life story of Milarepa, Milarepa finished doing a retreat for many years, and after many years Milarepa had great realization. Then Milarepa thought, "OK. Now, this is the time for me to teach. I should build a monastery, or I should build a meditation community." something like that. Then Milarepa had a vision of his teacher, who said, "Do not make a monastery. Do not make a particular institution of meditation. Do continuous retreat. Doing retreat, is one of the best ways to benefit future beings in Tibet."The life story of Milarepa has been the biggest inspiration in Tibet, also for me. All Tibetan masters and many lay people — boys, girls, men, women — everybody is inspired by Milarepa's love, kindness, compassion, diligence, and insight. Therefore, doing retreat is a very precious and valuable thing to do in the world. You have to recognize this. You have to appreciate that. Then it will really become meaningful to you, and meaningful to others.

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.title: The Benefits Of Retreat, Summary Of Key Points
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.description:
There are two types of meditation: Formal meditation
Informal meditation There are three types of retreat: Outer retreat - Environment
Inner retreat - Body and speech
Secret retreat - Mind There are three main benefits to retreat: You can fully dedicate your time to meditation
Unbroken continuation of the practice
You are automatically separated from the objects of negative emotions and negative behaviour There are three causes of negative emotions: The object is nearby
The negative tendency in your mind
Wrong motivation There are two ways to check if you are ready to do longer retreat: The waterfall experience has lessened in your daily practice
Weekend and weeklong retreats are not overwhelming (step-by-step approach) Example: Making a Fire
When the fire begins to burn, if you do not protect it from wind, etc., the fire will not get the chance to grow or it will take a long time for it to do so. Similarly, if you do not "protect" your practice by doing retreat, it will take much longer for your meditation to develop.
Retreat is an extension of formal/daily meditation practice.
Daily practice versus retreat is similar to having a part-time job or full-time job.
In the beginning, it is important to develop a steady daily practice.
After more time in retreat, your retreat experience will begin to merge with your day-to-day life.
The length of retreat is less important than its quality.
Even a short period of quality retreat time can change your life.
First focus on your daily practice, then do short retreats, and then do longer retreats.
The most important point is to develop some experience of meditation before doing retreat.
Even without doing retreat you can achieve direct realization. If you want to become buddha within one life, retreat is necessary.
If you cannot find time for daily formal practice, doing retreat is very important.
Doing one weekend retreat every month is very beneficial.
Group retreat is very beneficial in the beginning.
Once you have more experience of meditation, solitary retreat is better.
Solitary retreat is more beneficial for intermediate and advanced meditators.
Once you have some experience, doing long retreats is really good.
Long retreats can really transform your mind and the subtle body.
There are many different ways of practicing depending on your level and personality.
Listening to your heart and following your personality is also important.
aliases: The Benefits Of Retreat, Summary Of Key Points
the benefits of retreat, summary of key points
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.sourcePath: 3. Retreat Course/Additional Teachings/The Benefits of Retreat Summary of Key Points.md

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.title: The Challenges Of Retreat, Summary Of Key Points
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.description:
Two types of meditation experiences: Peaceful meditation experiences
Rough meditation experiences Three types of peaceful experiences: Clarity
Joy
Non-conceptuality Two types of rough experiences: Agitation Thoughts
Emotions Dullness Thoughts
Sleepiness Two ways to deal with peaceful experiences: Do not be attached to them
Appreciate them Attachment is related to two things: Permanence
Singularity Meditation experience comes with a taste, realization comes without a taste.
Rough experiences are good for realization.
Peaceful experiences are good for inspiration.
Rough and peaceful experiences are not obstacles to meditation. They are signs of progressing in meditation.
Quote
"For a mind that is really focused on meditation and focused on the dharma, the outside circumstances do not matter much."
— Milarepa There are four possibilities for a yogi: The body is in the mountains but the mind is in the city.
The body is in the city but the mind is in the mountains.
Both the body and the mind are in the mountains.
Neither the body nor the mind are in the mountains. With these four, the key point is that we should do our best to stay focused on the practice, especially when we are on retreat.
In order to prioritize practice, we need to change our habits.
The time and environment of practice does not really matter. What matters is the quality of the practice.
A few days of sincere, heartfelt practice in retreat can be life-changing.
If you cannot go to the mountains, make the city your mountain.
In the beginning, it is important to do short retreats.
By doing short retreats you will build up experience.
Example: Changing the Direction of a Train
If a train goes forward very fast and you would like to change the direction, first, you need to slow down. Similarly, if you want to change your habits, you need to first slow down and then implement changes one by one.
One of the easiest mistakes to make is being lazy in retreat.
Being attached to meditation experiences is a common mistake.
It is important to make room for and allow mistakes to happen.
Failure is the mother of success: When you attempt more, you will fail more, but this is how learning occurs.
Do not expect your retreat to be all wonderful and fantastic.
Stay with a clear structure of sessions and breaks.
Instead of being discouraged by your mistakes, appreciate them. The biggest challenges in retreat are internal.
The biggest internal challenge is the waterfall experience: the experience of agitated thoughts and intense emotions.
First, recognize the waterfall experience. Secondly, appreciate it.
We are attached to our unhappy situation, not because we particularly like it, but because it is familiar.
Feeling uncomfortable in retreat does not mean that something is wrong; it means that you are perfectly normal — this is what happens when we make changes to our environment.
You can use your sense of discomfort or loneliness in three ways: As a support for awareness
As a support for loving-kindness and compassion
As a support for emptiness Do not expect your difficult emotions to disappear right away. They will come back again, but slowly their power over you will diminish.
Try to appreciate the challenges you experience in retreat as opportunities to learn and grow. Energy movement are related to four things, two of which are deceptive and two of which are not: Sensory distortions — False
Sensing energy — False
Emotions are going up and down — True
Physical body sensations — True Do not take having visions of Buddhas, hearing special messages etc. to be true; simply view them as you would a movie.
When energy movement occurs, simply know that you are not enlightened and you are not crazy. It is just energy movement taking place.
Meditate for short times, many times and also do walking and standing meditation.

the challenges of retreat, summary of key points

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.title: The Importance Of Retreat
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.description: When we practice meditation, we need two types of meditation. One is what we call, "formal meditation," and the second is "informal meditation." Formal meditation means that you spend your time fully with your practice. Maybe you let go of your phone, you do not watch television, you do not communicate with others, you sit on your cushion, and your mind, body, and speech are fully dedicated to the meditation. If you do that, meditation develops very fast and it really gives you the best quality of your meditation. It improves your meditation a lot.The other one is informal meditation. The first important point is that you need to develop your meditation with formal meditation. Then, to exercise and to deepen the formal meditation with different circumstances, with different situations, you need informal meditation. With informal meditation, you can meditate everywhere, anytime, and under any circumstances — while you are talking, walking, in all places.Which one is important to do first? Formal meditation is important to do first. Formal meditation is like this: If you want to make a fire, first you need to have the right circumstances. You need tiny splinters of wood or grass, and then you can make a fire. Once the fire has become a little bit bigger, you can add more things. Once the fire becomes very big, you can add anything to the fire — big pieces of wood, strong wood, and other different things — everything you add helps the fire.Similarly, a retreat is kind of like extending the formal meditation. Of course, we do formal meditation everyday for one hour, twenty minutes, or something — which is great — but it takes time to develop your meditation this way. Instead, if you continue to maybe practice for two days, then one week, one month, one year, etc., with this unbroken continuation, will really help you to develop your meditation experience. It is like comparing having a part-time job and full-time job. If you work part-time, your achievements are less, right? But if you work full-time, there are a lot of benefits.Retreat is like being fully dedicated. And it is not only that, another benefit is the continuation — the benefit of the unbroken practice without being involved in other thoughts and emotions. For example: if you make a fire, when the fire becomes a little big bigger, if you then mix it with different circumstances, the fire will stay without not really developing. But, once the fire has really developed, if you then mix it with other circumstances it is okay, but doing it before that is quite difficult. Therefore, if we have the time, it is very important to do retreat.There are two benefits, right? The first is that you can fully spend time with your practice, and the second is the benefit of the unbroken continuation. There is also a third benefit. The third benefit is normally what we call — The causes of negative emotions, negative behaviour, negative habits, etc., all these come up because of three things: (1) The object is nearby, (2) the tendency in your mind, and (3) wrong motivation. When these three come together, negative actions may arise. One accumulate bad habits when all these come. So, we have the object and, also, deep in your mind you have not cut the root of negative emotions, plus, you have the wrong motivation.For example: When you are angry, if the person with whom you are angry is near you all the time — of course, you feel anger on the inside — and your motivation is, "If I get the opportunity to fight with that person, I am going to do so.," when these three come together, you will fight, and hit each other. But, if you do not have anger on the inside, and the person is there, then the situation will not produce negative emotions for you. Also, if you do not have the wrong motivation, even if you feel anger and the object of your anger is there, there will not be a result. If the object is not there, then, even if you have the wrong motivation and anger inside of you, it does not produce a result.To cut this negative emotion, and to change motivation, is very difficult for a beginner. For a beginner, if you are away from the object and environment (of your negative emotion), it really gives you an opportunity to stay away from negative actions and all these things. Therefore, retreat makes you stay away from negative environments. While you are away from the negative environments, you transform on the inside and develop wisdom, compassion, and awareness. Then, anger begins to liberate and, at the same time, you are transforming the negative motivation, and later, even if the object is there, it will be fine. Therefore, the third benefit is that you are automatically away from the objects of negative emotions and negative behaviour — all those things.In brief, retreat is really, really beneficial, normally. If you can do long retreat would be very good! But even a weekend retreat — Saturday and Sunday — is great! Every month we have four weekends, right? Three weekends you can spend on holidays or whatever you want to do, and one weekend you can do retreat. Therefore, even a two-days retreat will be really beneficial for you in order to boost your meditation experience.
