3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.title: The Meaning Of The 8 Offerings
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.description: By Khenpo Konchog Gyaltsen RinpocheThe subject here today is an explanation of the significance of the eight offerings. We make these offerings to the enlightened beings in many practices — in the Vajrasattva practice, guru yoga, and a lot of other practices. The enlightened beings do not want or need these things. We make offerings for our own benefit, to accumulate great merit and wisdom.Enlightenment, buddhahood, is achieved through the two great qualities — accumulation and purification. As you know, the Buddha has limitless qualities, which were gained through the great accumulations and purifications. Our offerings are a simple way to accumulate both merit and wisdom.Water To Cleanse The Mouth Or Face (Argham) – AuspiciousnessIt signifies auspiciousness or all the positive causes and conditions which bring positive effects. So, make an offering of water which is clean, fresh, cool, smooth, light, delicious, comfortable to the throat and stomach — these qualities are the qualities of auspiciousness. When you drink that kind of water, it is healthy; if you take a shower with it, it is healthy. While you make this kind of water offering to the enlightened beings, visualize an ocean of water.Then we dedicate this water to become a cause for all sentient beings to also collect positive causes and conditions. This is the first water offering — to cleanse the mouth or face.Water to Wash The Feet (Padyam) - PurificationThis is clear water mixed with incense or sandalwood which is made as an offering to all enlightened beings' feet. The symbolic meaning is purification. By cleansing the feet of the enlightened beings, we cleanse all our own negative karma and obscurations. By making offerings to clean the enlightened beings feet, we are really cleaning the "feet" of our own mind.With respect, devotion and confidence, we offer an ocean of this kind of water to all enlightened beings to purify all the temporary obscurations of ourselves and all sentient beings. Obscurations are called "temporary" because they can be purified. If they were permanent, we could not purify them even if we make an effort. So meditate on this when you make these offeringsAll the different types of obscurations — gross, subtle, negative karma, afflictive emotions, and obscurations to enlightenment — all these different types of obscurations become fully purified.Flowers (Pushpe) - GenerosityNext is offering of a flower, the flower of the beauty of enlightenment. It signifies the practice of generosity and opens the heart. A flower is very beautiful; so you naturally want to keep it.But when you offer it to others, there is some special feeling in the mind. With that connection, make the offering and practice freedom from stinginess. Milarepa said there is no special practice of generosity if one is free from stinginess. Meditate on that by offering flowers, which signifies the practice of generosity. "May all sentient beings Achieve the freedom and endowment Of a precious human life." Flowers are offered to the head of the enlightened beings, for them to wear on the crown of the head. Within the practice of generosity, we immediately think of giving wealth, giving fearlessness, giving wisdom — there are many different types of generosity.Usually, when we say generosity, we immediately think of giving wealth, but it is not only that. For example, giving fearlessness means giving life. If someone is afraid for their life, like drowning in water, and if you give them safety from the water, this is called, “giving fearlessness,” or “giving freedom from danger to life.”Giving wisdom is a very special kind of generosity. When we give teachings to someone who has no wisdom — who does not know what samsara is, what enlightenment is, or what the cause of suffering is — that is such a great gift. To help them understand "Oh, that is samsara, that is enlightenment." It is such a great gift! So, offering a flower symbolizes generosity.Incense (Dhupe) - Discipline or Moral EthicsMoral discipline is one of the most important practices. In the West, maybe discipline and morality are a little bit different. What I mean here is that when we have good discipline, there is morality. Discipline is in the teaching of the dharma. For instance, it says, "do this, this, and this. Sit like this, meditate like this." It is taught like discipline. So when we do that, it is good moral ethics; when we cannot do these things that are taught to be done, then there is no morality, no ethics.In Sanskrit, this is called, “shila.” Shila means, “coolness,” or “freshness.” When we have good discipline, it cools the mind free from suffering. When we stay in that position well, it relaxes the mind and frees it from agitation. All these disciplines are part of the process of progressing in our meditation practice. Unless these disciplines and moral ethics are there, it is not possible to achieve enlightenment.Therefore, Buddha gave these three teachings — moral ethics, samadhi and wisdom — called, “the three trainings.” These three trainings are very important. Wisdom or special insight comes from samadhi (meditation), the stability and strength of the mind. That kind of strength in the mind is based on discipline and morality. So they are all related to each other, are connected to each other, and depend on each other.Therefore, moral ethics is a very important aspect of the path. Incense, which is the nature of morality, makes offerings to the nose of the enlightened beings. The enlightened beings are not attached to smell, but to our purity. All people respect those who have kept moral ethics well. It does not matter who they are, they get respect because they are trustworthy and dependable. That kind of person gives a good smell, good odor, and people are attracted to that. not only people, but the qualities of enlightened beings are also attracted by that morality. It is their foundation/basis, like the ground which grows all the "crops" of the enlightened qualities.Light (Aloke) - PatienceFifth is light or a lamp, which signifies the stability and clarity of patience, the beauty which dispels all ignorance. The light offering is made to the eyes of all the enlightened beings, who see clearly without mistake. Some people feel patience is showing weakness or pessimism. But, actually, patience shows the strength and clarity of mind, which are based on wisdom and compassion.Without proper wisdom and compassion, one cannot practice patience. So light shows the strength of the mind, the clear, stable nature of the mind, achieved through the practice of patience. Because the mind is not disturbed by other forces, it has such great qualities: clarity knows what is to be done — what is necessary, and what is not necessary. That dispels ignorance.Patience can be practiced in all different forms, different ways, not just when people are faced with anger. For example, there is patience in dharma practice and study. First, this is based on wisdom, so we should have such wisdom to really know how dharma is, what quality it has, the depth and vastness of dharma, and how we can achieve these qualities. Seeing those great qualities, then we need patience to study and practice. When we have that, there is a mind of clarity, of stability.On the other hand, we should not be patient with our afflictive emotions. When we have anger, desire, jealousy, pride, do not practice patience with these! This is the wrong way to practice patience. Even if it is hard or painful, these are subjects to get rid of or purify; they do not do any good thing. Without sacrificing something, there is no chance that we will have peace and happiness. So no matter what kind of pain we face, what difficult circumstances we face, we have to go thru it. Even if we have to sacrifice this life, it is worthwhile to sacrifice.A lot of people commit suicide to get rid of all these afflictive emotions. They are overpowered by the afflictive emotions and they kill themselves. That is the wrong way to sacrifice this life. We have to sacrifice this life the other way around. Buddha said that if we have to lose our life to keep the moral discipline, it just finishes this life, but next lives will be higher and higher, better and better. But if we do it the other way around and sacrifice this life for the afflictive emotions, then we will go worse and worse.In Shantideva's text it is said that we should not commit suicide or give this body without much purpose. Rather, we should cherish this precious human life. An explanation is given. When a medicinal tree is a very small plant, it has to be protected in order to grow into a huge tree. If you pick it up when it is small, it will benefit only a few and then it is finished. But if you protect it well, with many fences, it will grow into a huge tree that will bring fruits, flowers, roots, leaves, branches for the benefit of many, many sentient beings.Similarly, we have a fragile mind at this time. We must protect this precious human life with all these antidotes, fences, and let it grow big. Then we can benefit many sentient beings. By the practice of patience, all the 112 major and minor marks of a Buddha will come. Of course, we should not expect it, but the result of patience is a healthy, good body, to which all people are attracted, which is respected and admired. All this comes from the practice of patience.Fragrance (Gandhe) - PerserveranceNext is the offering of perfume or the fragrance of saffron or sandalwood — all the different types of perfume. That signifies perseverance or joyous effort. Through that one quality, one develops all the qualities of enlightenment. Without perseverance, without joyous effort, nothing can be achieved. Even in samsara, we have to work so hard to achieve anything. A lot of people sacrifice a lot of things just for samsaric achievement. You sacrifice your life for your work; if you die, what will you do with your wealth? So now, see the other side — dharma study and practice. When we could make such a great effort to study and practice dharma, we have to sacrifice some little thing.It is said in Shantideva's text that studying dharma is the cause to freedom from suffering. To achieve ultimate enlightenment, ultimate happiness, why can’t we do that? Others in samsara , they even sacrifice their lives for their achievements, but that becomes a cause only for suffering.As flowers were offered to the eyes of enlightenment, perfumes are offered to the Buddha's mind, because perseverance is the heart of enlightenment. Perfect generosity, moral ethics, patience, samadhi, wisdom — these all depend on perseverance. Without joyous effort none of these can be accomplished, so it is the heart, the essence. Meditate that by this offering, may all sentient beings progress in their attainment of the qualities of enlightenment.Delicious Food (Naivedye) - SamadhiSeventh is the offering of delicious food, which has a lot of different tastes. The delicious, excellent quality of food signifies samadhi, which is a nectar or ambrosia to feed the mind. This is an offering to the tongue of the enlightened beings — the buddhas and bodhisattvas. Samadhi is also the source of all the siddhis, like clairvoyance.There are two different types of clairvoyance. Ordinary clairvoyance is usually from other lifetimes. The other type is special insight clairvoyance, which we achieve this lifetime through meditation practice. Flying in the sky, different types of miraculous power, these can all be achieved through samadhi, the virtuous one-pointed mind.The very stable mind, one-pointed, clear, calm, peaceful mind of samadhi becomes a basis to achieve all the enlightenment qualities. Food symbolizes samadhi because eating food maintains this body, and samadhi is a kind of food that maintains the mind as well as the physical body.When you achieve any kind of samadhi, it is the fruition of the effort you made before, and it can also become a path to get higher fruition. Generally, when we eat nutritious healthy food, it makes our health better. So if we have the nutritious food of samadhi, it keeps the health of the mind. It makes the mind healthy, clear, calm and peaceful. By making this offering of delicious food, may all sentient beings have the health which results from the samadhi food. May all sentient beings have the samadhi nature, quality.Musical Instruments (Shabdha) - WisdomThere are different types of instruments — cymbals, bells, guitars, lutes — all of these are offered. Their nature is wisdom, which makes an offering to the ears of the buddhas and bodhisattvas, and all the enlightened beings.Sound represents wisdom, because wisdom is a special power of the mind which penetrates phenomena. Compassion is achieved through great wisdom; interdependence of all phenomena is realized through great wisdom. Of course, all phenomena have the nature of interdependence, causes and conditions, but sound is especially easy to understand. If you play a guitar, what does the sound depend on? It does not come just from the piece of wood, the string, not from the finger. So where does it come from? It comes from all these things. None alone is sufficient to produce the sound. That nature is called, “illusion.” We can hear the Sound, but it has no independent existence. So we should see all sound having that nature. It just comes and goes like an echo. That realization is wisdom, and through that realization we can attain supramundane quality. May the wisdom, that quality of the supra-mundane, Arise within the minds of all sentient beings And free them from all confusion and ignorance. May they achieve enlightenment. edited from a talk by Khenpo Konchog Gyaltsen Rinpoche (5/1/1993) https://sacred-texts.com/bud/tib/kkgroffr.htm

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.title: The Role Of Retreat In The Buddhist Tradition
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.description: When you look at Buddha's life story, at first, Buddha went to many different places and received a variety of teachings from different teachers in India during that time. At first, Buddha was a prince and his father was a very powerful king. The king was afraid that Buddha would not become his successor, so the king tried to treat Buddha very well, keep him in the palace, and provide Buddha with whatever he needed. But, Buddha was aware of everything and then he began to ask questions about life; "What is the meaning of life?" Buddha saw someone that was sick and someone who was aging — all those things — and Buddha renounced the palace and looked for many different teachers. He did some short retreats. He received teachings and then he did some short retreats. In the end, once Buddha had received all the teachings, he went to sit next to the river Neranjara. Buddha did retreat for six years continuously. After that, Buddha got this big realization. Then, Buddha went to sit under the Bodhi tree and achieved full enlightenment. So, retreat is very important.Since that time, all the masters who have achieved high level of realization have all done retreat. In the Kagyu tradition, from Telo (Tilopa), Naro (Naropa) — those are the Indian masters — they all did retreat. Tilopa did retreat for twelve years, and Naropa did retreat for many years. Then Marpa and Milarepa also did retreat in one place for twelve years. By doing retreat, they achieved full realization. Especially in the Kagyu lineage, retreat is really important.If you do retreat, then you can really develop your meditation experience very fast. Like Milarepa's main disciple, Gampopa. Gampopa came to see Milarepa. Gampopa was very learned. He had studied all the scriptures, Buddhist philosophy, and he also knew Tibetan medicine. He was what we call a, “tönpa.” Tönpa means "professor." Gampopa himself was a professor, so he was very learned. He did some retreat for a few months and he got good meditation experience.Later on he came to Milarepa and he received deeper levels of meditation teachings. Milarepa spent his whole life in retreat, and next to Milarepa there was another cave in which Gampopa was, and Milarepa asked Gampopa to do retreat there. Gampopa had a lot of different levels of experience. Gampopa stayed like this with Milarepa for three years, and within these three years, roughly 85% of the time Gampopa spent in retreat.In the end, Milarepa said, "OK. Now I have taught you everything — all the important teachings from my teacher — so our lineage has passed down to you. Now, go back to your hometown and do retreat. Near your hometown, there is a mountain called, ‘Gampo mountain,’ you should go there and do retreat." Gampopa became a little bit sad. He really wanted to be with Milarepa, but Milarepa had asked him to go back. It was OK. Gampopa accepted and then Milarepa escorted Gampopa. Then, there was a bridge — a stone bridge — and a small river, and Milarepa sat next to the bridge on a rock. Then he spoke his final words to Gampopa. Milarepa said, "You came here and received all these teachings, and now you should go. I gave you all the teachings, everything, except one — the most important one I have not given you yet. This teaching is too precious, so I will not give it to you. Other than that, you have received everything, so now you can go." Gampopa became a little bit sad. But anyway, Gampopa said goodbye, crossed the bridge, and went far away. Then, from far away Milarepa was waiving his hand, "Hello! Come back! Come back!" Gampopa became happy and returned back. Milarepa said, "OK. You are a very good student, so I will teach you the final one." Gampopa became very happy. He said, "What should I do? Should I offer a mandala?" This is the traditional way to request teachings. Milarepa said, "There is no need. Instead, look here." and Milarepa showed his butt to Gampopa. Milarepa's butt had become like a monkey’s butt, because Milarepa had done retreat so long in the mountains without a proper cushion. He did not have a nice cushion, so he was sitting on the rocks, and Milarepa's butt became like a monkey's. It looked like a monkey’s butt. Then, Milarepa said, "Why do you think my butt became like a monkey’s butt? Because, I sit and practice and practice, and do retreat. Therefore, my butt has become like a monkey's butt. Once you receive teachings, the most important teaching is practice — to do retreat, and practice and practice. Now, I have already taught you the last important teaching, so now you can go back." Then Gampopa said goodbye and went back to his hometown.Back home he met his colleagues — there was a lot of professors there from his past. They all said, "Come here! Come here! You should teach this. You should study that." So, he stayed with them in the monastery and he forgot about doing retreat and meditating. After some time, his meditation started to go down. Then one day, he remembered Milarepa's words. So, he left everything. He went to that particular mountain that Milarepa had asked him to, and did retreat for about six years at first. In the end, Gampopa achieved high level of realization — he achieved enlightenment.Therefore, doing retreat continuously is very important. This is very important especially among the Kagyupas. In Buddhism in general it is important, but especially among the Kagyupas the role of retreat is very important.

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.title: The Unique Benefits Of Retreat
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/t.description: If you do retreat, your full concentration goes to your own practice and meditation without any breaks, and you are away from the environment. In one way, it is like having a part-time job or full-time job. Another thing is that you can be fully dedicated. Therefore, daily practice is when you are doing a little bit everyday. It is slow, with a lot of interruptions and different environments around you. In the beginning, you cannot transform all of this into your practice — it is quite difficult. You will fail and practice, and then fail again. But, there is nothing wrong with this way — it is OK. At the beginning, to do very long retreats is not something that we normally recommend. First, you do daily practice. This is very important.Meditation is like doing physical exercise. Even if you can exercise full-time, you cannot exercise the whole day. Therefore, at first, daily formal meditation is very important. Maybe you can do a mini-retreat. It becomes a very manageable way to do retreat. This is for formal meditation.Once your formal meditation becomes quite good, you can sometimes do retreat. At first, you can do retreat for two or three days, then you can extend it to one week, and slowly you can begin to do longer ones — this way would be beneficial, it would be good.If you really spend time with the process, developing a habit, and you understand what retreat is, and you have this feeling of wanting to practice, then retreat is really of benefit. But, nowadays many people do retreat, but they do it suddenly, or they do not know exactly what they have to practice, so even though they do retreat, their minds wander all over the world. So, the time is gone, your body is in the retreat house but your mind wanders around the world. That kind of retreat is not of so much benefit. People did retreat for many, many years, but they did not change or transform. It is like you stay in the gym the whole day but you are not doing any exercise. You are just sleeping at the gym the whole day. Even if you spend six months there, it will not be of so much benefit. If it is that kind of retreat, then just doing one hour of full dedication to one's meditation, is of more benefit than doing a few months of retreat. Therefore, the quality of retreat is really important. If you have a good quality retreat, then it is really of more benefit than just doing daily practice.Normally, our daily practice is like a fire that starts a little bit, but then some interruption comes — it can be the wind, or having a block of wood that is too big so the fire cannot burn it, and sometimes the fire goes out, and then it starts again, a little bit. Doing it this way takes time. Daily practice is like that. But, this is important in the beginning. You learn from it. You fail, but you learn from it. Next time, you know how to start a fire better. So, you start it again, and again it goes out, but you learn more and more each time. Normally, this is what we call, "Failure is the mother of success." But, if you do retreat, then the fire starts, and it burns while having the right protection, and it becomes bigger and bigger and bigger. Once the fire becomes bigger, having wind is OK, adding big blocks of wood is OK, or even if stones or different things fall in, it is OK. After that, what becomes important is informal meditation.Some people, after they have finished their retreat, they come down and they mix meditation with their daily life, they mix meditation with problems, they mix meditation with different circumstances, and they go to meditate with difficult persons — the object is there. When they meditate with rough and challenging circumstances, with their problems, then everything becomes part of their practice.Normally, we need two things: formal meditation, and informal meditation. These two need a bond between each other. If you just do daily meditation — both formal and informal — you still have this quality. It does not mean that if you do not do retreat for a long time, you will not get any experience — it is not like that. You will, but the experience is similar to the part-time job experience. If you continue to do good quality and unbroken continuous retreat, then it is really beneficial to you.I really like to do retreat. All my teachers have done a lot of retreats. It has been of real benefit to me. In the future, once you do retreat, after some time you will bring your retreat experience into daily life. Then, in the end, everything becomes part of retreat, because there will be no obstacles. Even bad situations, even bad environments, everything will transform. Therefore, doing retreat is like making a fire — it is just the same.

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/u.title: Understanding The Shrine
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/u.description:
A shrine holds the symbolic representations of the Buddha’s body, speech, and mind, and correspondingly, the three jewels — the Buddha, dharma and sangha. These are represented by a statue, a book, and a stupa.The image of the Buddha is a symbolic representation of the enlightened body of the Buddha. This could be a statue, or a thangka. If you want to have a somewhat more elaborate shrine, Mingyur Rinpoche suggests that we include a White Tara image, or statue. This could be placed to the left of the Buddha (when facing the shrine). The Tara statue could be somewhat smaller than the statue of the Buddha.A text represents the enlightened speech of the Buddha i.e., the teachings of the dharma. The text used could be written in any language. It could be the Heart Sutra if you wish to represent all of the teachings of the Buddha, or it can be a particular text related to your practice. It could go in front to the left of the Buddha (when facing the shrine).A stupa represents the enlightened mind of the Buddha. This is typically placed to the right of the image of the Buddha. The stupa could also be somewhat smaller than the statue of the Buddha.Lamps or candles symbolize wisdom that eliminates the darkness of ignorance.Use seven bowls for the water offering. These could be metal (brass or silver) or glass. Start with fresh water every day. Place the bowls in a straight line, close together but not touching. The bowls should be filled up to the space of a grain's width from the top.The seven water bowls represent the “Seven Limbs of Offering”. Each offering bowl symbolizes one of the seven offerings (from left to right): Prostrations Plant the seeds for attaining the qualities of enlightenment Purify karma of body, speech and mind Counteract pride Offering Overcomes miserliness Accumulates merit Declaration of misdeeds Acknowledgement of misdeeds Overcomes non-virtue Purifies karma Rejoicing in merit Overcomes jealousy Engenders sympathetic joy and appreciation Requesting the Buddhas to turn the wheel Counteracts wrong views Requesting the Buddhas to remain Plants the seeds that will ripen in Buddhahood Dedication of merit Seals merit Overcomes self-cherishing If you choose, when you fill the bowls you could recite the “Seven Limbs of Offering” (left to right): "I prostrate to the Buddha, dharma and sublime sangha I make offerings with my body, speech and mind I confess all non-virtuous deeds I rejoice in the virtue of all beings I request the buddhas to turn the wheel of the dharma I beseech the buddhas not to pass into nirvana I dedicate all merit to all sentient beings throughout the three times” Another symbolic meaning of the water bowls is that just as the moon’s reflection in the water is the same in each of the bowls, the compassion of the Buddha shines equally for all beings.Normally placed on a shrine as offerings to the senses of the Buddha. The flowers could be cut flowers placed on either side of the Buddha. If potted plants are used, they should be placed on the floor on either side of the shrine. You could use regular candles, or glass oil candles. The incense can be placed in an incense burner, a small bowl of sand on the floor, or a small stand in front of the shrine.When setting up a shrine for an empowerment, a Vajrayana feast, or if your daily yidam practice requires it, you will want to present the “inner offerings” on your shrine in place of the water bowls. The seven inner offerings are: Water to Cleanse Mouth or Face (Argham) - Auspiciousness Water to Wash the Feet (Padyam) - Purification Flowers (Pushpe) - Generosity Incense (Dhupe) - Discipline, Moral Ethics Light (Aloke) - Patience Fragrance (Gandhe) - Perserverance Deliciouis Food (Naivedye) - Samadhi Musical Instruments (Shabda) - Wisdom A shrine is a symbolic representation of the Buddha, dharma and sangha, and an expression of our own inspiration and appreciation. A shrine reminds us of the three jewels. It has the power to tame and uplift a space where we gather with sangha friends to practice. A room with a shrine offers us place of inspiration and peace. Sacred spaces have been used in this way throughout time.On an inner level, we are drawn to emulate the three jewels. We go for refuge in the truth of the infallible three jewels symbolized by the objects on the shrine. Through creating this space and relating with the representations of the three jewels, we deepen our connection, our respect, and devotion.A shrine and a sacred space create the environment for the power and blessings of the three jewels and the lineage to manifest. Such an environment allows us to directly experience the sanity and wisdom symbolized by the shrine. This is not merely a psychological shift; rather, with the help of the symbolic power and wisdom represented by the shrine, we are actually able to invoke the mind of the lineage.At the end of the day, before or at sunset, empty the bowls one by one, dry them with a clean cloth and stack them upside down. Offer the water to the plants in your house or in the garden. Here's a lovely teaching on How to Set Up a Buddhist Shrine - by Ven. Tenzin Yignyen of Namgyal Monastery.
For more information about the inner offerings, read the document "The Meaning of the 8 Offerings". This document can be found in the resources for retreat.↩︎

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/w.title: What To Expect From Retreat
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/w.description: Many people, when they hear about the idea of doing retreat, feel so happy. "If I can do retreat I will be stress-free. I will have a lot of time for peace and joy. And then, my meditation will develop very quickly." Ideas have a lot of fantasies inside. Is this the right kind of expectations? If you want to do retreat, should you have those expectations or not? My answer is, "Not." These ideas are not so good ideas. Normally, we say that when you do retreat, at the beginning, good motivation is really important. "I want to do retreat to be able to benefit. Of course, myself, and by helping myself, I will be able to help my friends, family, colleagues, society, the world, and all beings." That motivation is important. Do not think, "I will be in retreat and it will be fantastic! I will transform right away, and I will have joy and peace and all these things." If you have these kinds of expectations and do retreat, then your retreat will not be so wonderful — you will be disappointed. Therefore, normally, we say, do not have too high expectations. Let go of these expectations.So, what should you expect? "I will do this retreat..." in Tibet, what we call, "Tsam." As you enter this special boundary, 30% of negative actions will not happen, because you are away from the objects of negative emotions and actions, right? That is already great! You need to really appreciate even a tiny transformation, a tiny virtue, tiny things that are related to non-violence and other things, related with kindness and compassion — you just appreciate this. "That would be good. As long as I am not making negative actions, as long as I am not on purpose harming others, that would be great!" That is the kind of motivation. Just an appreciation of the basic things, and then go to retreat.Then, if you can do some things even better, you will have more appreciation, you will have more feelings of inspiration. You will not be afraid of this waterfall experience. In fact, the waterfall experience is a good sign. You have to recognize that the waterfall experience is a good sign. This is also a really important motivation when you begin to do retreat.If you do retreat together with many people, sometimes the monkey mind projects onto your friends and colleagues in the retreat. "Maybe he does not like me today? Today he said, 'Huh huh! a little bit stronger than yesterday. That means that he is sending me some kind of signal that he does not like me." Or, "My friend slammed the door, very strongly. I think he does not like me." These things might appear sometimes when you practice. But, these are part of the waterfall experience. Let it be, let go, and it will go away. You will have joy, peace, and the experience of clarity. After some time later, that will not last. Then, dullness, agitation, and these things come back again. It goes up and down, up and down. Eventually, it will become better, and better, and better. Therefore, have the right motivation, and when you do retreat do not expect too much, and do not give up.This is really important.

3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/w.title: Working With Positive Meditation Experiences
3.-retreat-course/additional-teachings/w.description:
Normally, there are three types of positive experiences: clarity, joy, and non-conceptuality. These are the three categories. When you have these positive experiences, what do you have to do? There are two things that are important: One, do not be attached to it. Secondly, appreciate it.When I learned meditation for the first time my father said:
"Do not be attached to meditation experience."
Then I really tried to think about not being attached to my meditation experience. I was thinking about that a lot. When I meditated, as soon as I had some good meditation experience I got worried. "Am I being attached? Oh. I am attached now. I should not be attached! What should I do?" There was so much worrying. Then I asked my father, "You said when meditating there are meditation experiences. When there are good meditation experiences I should not be attached but I cannot help being attached. It seems like there is always attachment around my meditation." I asked my father this, and my father said, "What is your attachment?" I told my father about my attachments and my father explained to me that there is a difference between appreciation and attachment. At that time, I was confused about being attached to my meditation and appreciating my meditation. When you have good meditation experiences you can appreciate it, that is not a problem. You can have gratitude towards your good meditation experience, appreciate your good meditation experience, this is very important, but do not be attached to it.What is the difference between attachment and appreciation? Attachment has two things: being related to permanence and being related to singularity. The meaning of permanence is that when you have this wonderful experience, you want to have the same experience again and again, and you might think, "From now on, it will be like this forever." That is wrong expectations. That is what we call, "Attachment to permanence."Sometimes when I meditated, especially when I got new meditation experiences, I felt so happy. At that time I thought, "I think this is not just an experience, this is realization!" Because normally I was looking for realization. Then I heard a lot about the qualities of realization;
"Realization is like space.
Meditation experiences are like clouds.
Once you get realization it is never lost."
Of course it is never lost, but realization does not have a "taste." Meditation experience has a taste. The meaning of "taste" is that when you are meditating you feel so happy, like, "Mmm... Aha! Oho!" (Mingyur Rinpoche pretends to be blissful.) That is the experience. Realization is that you become like that. There is no taste. You become the taste, maybe. (Mingyur Rinpoche laughs.)Anyway, in the beginning, we will have experiences. Experiences are good. There is nothing wrong about having experiences, whether that are good experiences or bad experiences, both are good, actually. Especially for realization, bad experiences are very good. Good experiences are good for inspiration, it is good for feeling appreciation and gratitude. But there is a danger also. The danger is that you might become attached to that good experience. Bad experiences are very good for developing realization, especially detachment. But with some people, we do not know if the bad experiences are similar to the good ones. We may get stuck in the bad experiences as well. We think, "There is something wrong with me. I am bad." Especially, you might think that bad experiences are a problem to meditation, but they are actually not. Bad experiences are the result of meditation, it is the sign of meditation. It is what we call, "waterfall experience." Therefore, there are plus and minus to both, but you have to know how to deal with that.With good experiences, do not be attached. The attachment to permanence means that you think, "It will be like this forever. From now on, I will have no problem with my monkey mind." This is wrong. Do not be attached.Attachment has two things. One is permanence which is finished, and the second one is attachment related to singularity. Singularity means, "This is the best!" Some people think, "I will be enlightened tomorrow! I think I have achieved a high level of enlightenment. If I share this with my teacher tomorrow, my teacher will be really happy and give me a special promotion (Mingyur Rinpoche laughs.) I am just kidding about the promotion, but you might think, "I am enlightened. I am the best. I am number one. No-one else knows about this wonderful experience." This is the meaning of singularity. Do not think that this is enlightenment. Do not think that this is realization. It is not realization. It is not enlightenment. It is just an experience. But having this experience is really good. It is good for you in order to develop appreciation.Normally, we say, "Experience is the sign of realization." We have an example of this: In the morning, before the sunrise, before the real sun comes out, a light comes, sunlight. Everything becomes bright and slowly everything gets a maroon sort of color. The light is not the sun but it is the sign that the sun is coming. Similarly, experience is the sign of realization. Therefore, before realization, we will have these experiences.How do we deal with these experiences? One important technique is to not be attached to it. What is the meaning of not being attached to it? Think that, "This is an experience. Who knows, tomorrow it might be completely gone? It is impermanent. It is not enlightenment. But it is the sign of meditation." You can appreciate this. "How nice! I have this wonderful experience." Feel gratitude. Then, these good experiences will become the cause to achieve direct realization in the future. Eventually, you will have a realization that is free from experience. Eventually, you will reach that state.

Jetsunma Tenzin Palmo is an author, teacher and founder of the Dongyu Gatsal Ling Nunnery in Himachal Pradesh, India. She moved to India at the age of 20 and in 1964 became only the second Western woman to be ordained in the Tibetan tradition. Tenzin Palmo completed a remarkable 12 year solo retreat in a cave in Lhadak. She has since has been deeply engaged in advocating for and training young nuns in India. Quote "While all beings have great wisdom and compassion, this is not always apparent. This is simply because they have not recognized what they already have. Thus, aside from merely recognizing our own true nature, there isn't the slightest thing to meditate on. Recognizing the importance of this, I have passed my days feeling joyful and content, wandering through the mountains and valleys and staying here and there. From my heart, I sincerely encourage all of you to practice diligently in this manner as well." — Mingyur Rinpoche, while on retreat Dedicated periods of practice in retreat have been a central part of the Buddhist tradition from the time of the historical Buddha. Retreat gives us the time and space to explore our experience and discover aspects of our own being that are difficult to connect with in everyday life. Retreat is not without its challenges, but those who make time for this transformative practice often find it an indispensable support on the path of awakening.The course includes advice on retreat from Mingyur Rinpoche and other contemporary teachers as well as traditional resources on retreat such as Jamgon Kongtrul's Retreat Manual, Dudjom Rinpoche's Mountain Dharma, and the Life of Milarepa.
The instructors recommend that participants obtain a copy of The Life of Milarepa in print or digital form as the book will be used throughout the course. There are two translations available, one by Lobsang P. Lhalungpa and one by Andrew Quintman.
Visit the Retreat Resources page for schedules and shrine information, and the discussion forum to ask the course guides questions.Course Dates Starting March 15, 2024 Live Sessions Join upcoming Heart-to-Heart and Practice sessions, and access recordings.

3.-retreat-course/setting-up-a-shrine.ht.title: Setting Up A Shrine
3.-retreat-course/setting-up-a-shrine.ht.description: A shrine holds the symbolic representations of the Buddha’s body, speech, and mind, and correspondingly, the Three Jewels — the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.The image of the Buddha is a symbolic representation of enlightened form. This could be a statue, or a thangka of Shakyamuni Buddha, White Tara, or any deity. This could be placed to the left of the Buddha (when facing the shrine).A text represents enlightened speech, the teachings of the Dharma. The text used could be written in any language. Typically, this text would come from the Prajnaparamita tradition, such as the Heart Sutra. It should be placed in the front, left of the Buddha (when facing the shrine).A stupa represents the awakened mind. This is typically placed to the right of the image of the Buddha. The stupa could also be somewhat smaller than the statue of the Buddha. Mingyur Rinpoche has said that if you use a picture of the Buddha or deity, a simple card with the Heart Sutra, and a picture of a stupa, this would be perfectly fine.If you wish, your shrine could include candles, water bowls, incense, and flowers. Mingyur Rinpoche has said that these are not essential, and that, if you do not have these, or want to take a simple approach, you could simply offer a plate with some fruit.Use seven bowls for the water offering. These could be metal (brass or silver) or glass. Start with fresh water every day. Place the bowls in a straight line, close together but not touching. The bowls should be filled up to the space of a grain's width from the top.The seven water bowls represent the “Seven Limbs of Offering”. Each offering bowl symbolizes one of the seven offerings (from left to right): prostrating, offering, confession, rejoicing in merit, requesting the Buddhas to remain, requesting them to teach, and dedicating the merit.Another symbolic meaning of the water bowls is that just as the moon reflection in the water is the same in each of the bowls, the compassion of the Buddha shines equally for all beings.These are also often placed on a shrine as offerings to the senses of the Buddha. The flowers could be cut flowers placed on either side of the Buddha. If potted plants are used, they should be placed on the floor on either side of the shrine. Lamps or candles symbolize wisdom that eliminates the darkness of ignorance. You could use regular candles or glass oil candles. The incense can be placed in an incense burner, or a small bowl of sand on the floor, or small stand in front of the shrine.When setting up a shrine for an empowerment, a Vajrayana feast, or if your daily yidam practice requires it, you will want to present the “inner offerings” on your shrine in place of the water bowls. The seven inner offerings are: water to cleanse the mouth or face, water to wash the feet, flowers, light, incense, food, and music.For more information regarding the symbolic meaning of the shrine, refer to the document "Understanding the Shrine," which can be found in the resource section.

3.-retreat-course/tips-for-structuring-a.title: Tips For Structuring A Retreat
3.-retreat-course/tips-for-structuring-a.description: This guideline could be used for a one day retreat, weekend retreat, or longer. The guidelines and principles of retreat practice remain the same regardless of the length of retreat. During your retreat you will want to be alone. It’s best not to see or talk with anyone, or engage in distractions — using the internet, listening to the radio, etc. Try to maintain silence during the retreat. If possible, do the retreat in a place where you won’t hear people talking.The day is spent meditating, with a little time allotted for reading and contemplation. You could take a book for study and contemplation, or perhaps, a book to inspire you, such as a life story of a great meditator from the past. In general, your reading should support and inspire your practice. Reading and study are not meant to be the focus of a meditation retreat.On the first morning, take a few minutes to reflect on your aspiration for the retreat. You might contemplate the qualities that you would like to emphasize, or what you would like to learn from the retreat. You could open each day with an aspiration and close the day with a dedication.During the breaks you could spend time reading and contemplating. You could also choose to do something physical to stay fresh, such as stretching, yoga, or Tai Chi. If you’re in an isolated place, you could practice walking meditation.Start your first session with whatever opening liturgies are appropriate to the practice that you are doing. This could include, among others, the lines for taking Refuge and arousing Bodhichitta, the Four Immeasurables, and a lineage supplication. You can add whatever other liturgies that you choose, such as the Heart Sutra.End each session with a Dedication of Merit. You could also add whatever else you choose, such as long life supplications, aspirations, etc.It’s always best to decide on the schedule that you want to maintain at the beginning of the retreat and try to stay with it.Quote "In a remote place, where the thought of death pierces the heart, The retreatant, who has profoundly turned away from attachment Draws the boundary, giving up all concerns for this life, Hence, his mind is not involved with the eight worldly dharmas" — The words of Karak Gomchung, quoted often by Mingyur Rinpoche's father, Tulku Urgyen Rinpoche. 4.-mahamudra-course/module-1.-mahamudra-.title: Module 1: Mahamudra 101
4.-mahamudra-course/module-1.-mahamudra-.description:
Mahamudra is considered the most powerful and direct path to awakening in the Kagyu lineage. This experiential approach focuses on recognizing the mind’s empty clarity, and then stabilizing this recognition until it becomes an uninterrupted flow of experience that is integrated with all aspects of life. It allows the meditator to use every thought, emotion, and perception as a gateway to the awakened nature of mind and to see every aspect of experience as an expression of buddha nature.In this module we will explore the fundamentals of the Mahamudra lineage, learning about the meaning of the term “Mahamudra” and the key points of Mahamudra practice. We will see that the term “Mahamudra” can be used to refer to the nature of reality, to a lineage of Buddhist practice that originated in ancient India, and also to a set of practical meditation instructions that guide the meditator to an experience of the mind’s true nature. We will also learn about the ground, path, and fruition of Mahamudra and the four points that serve as the foundation for Mahamudra practice.

4.-mahamudra-course/module-2.-mahamudra-.title: Module 2: Mahamudra Shamatha
4.-mahamudra-course/module-2.-mahamudra-.description:
The Mahamudra path consists of stabilizing the experience of awareness through shamatha meditation and exploring the nature of mind through the practice of vipashyana meditation.The traditional analogy for these two forms of meditation is that vipashyana is like the illuminating flame of a candle, and shamatha is like a glass enclosure that protects the flame and magnifies its light. In the context of Mahamudra meditation, vipashyana helps us to recognize the empty clarity of the mind, and shamatha enables us to stabilize this recognition and integrate it with every aspect of our lives.In this module we will explore the unique presentation of shamatha meditation found in the Mahamudra lineage. Our exploration will introduce the different forms of shamatha practice, including the use of the breath, sensory objects, and other supports for awareness, as well as the practice of open awareness. We will also learn about the stages of shamatha meditation and important principles, such as tightening and loosening the focus of attention.

4.-mahamudra-course/mahamudra-course-ove.title: Mahamudra Course Overview
4.-mahamudra-course/mahamudra-course-ove.description:
Cortland Dahl on the 2019 Mahamudra Course Welcome to the Course Workbook Orientation Tips for Path of Liberation Mahamudra is considered the most profound and direct path to awakening in the Kagyu school of Tibetan Buddhism. This lineage of practical instructions helps us to experience the radiant purity of awareness and to stabilize this experience and integrate it with every aspect of our lives. For centuries, teachings on Mahamudra have been passed down by some of Tibet’s greatest masters, including Milarepa and Gampopa.In this course, we will learn the most important principles and practices of the Mahamudra tradition. Our journey will be based on important texts from the Mahamudra lineage and video teachings from Mingyur Rinpoche on key points of nature of mind practice. The course will also include live webinars with Mingyur Rinpoche and Tergar instructors, discussion forums, an extensive Mahamudra workbook to deepen understanding and experience, and a range of other resources for study and practice.Throughout the Mahamudra course, we return to three familiar points of reference: understanding the view, gaining experience through meditation, and the application of our practice in everyday life. The discussion questions, reflection exercises, and meditation suggestions offered in the course workbook are designed to help you deepen your experience and understanding in these three areas.Each module of the Mahamudra course will provide teachings, readings and practice instructions on the fundamentals of Mahamudra. In the first three modules of the course, we progress from the essential meaning of Mahamudra to the practices of Mahamudra shamatha and vipashyana. In the last two modules, we will explore the nature of mind, the unfolding of experience along the path, and the stages of realization.Below is an outline of the course by topic and length of time spent on each topic during the course from September through March. Module 1: Mahamudra 101 (4 weeks)
Module 2: Mahamudra Shamatha (4 weeks)
Module 3: Mahamudra Vipashyana (6 weeks)
Module 4: Pointing Out the Nature of Mind (4 weeks)
Module 5: Path and Fruition (6 weeks)

Core Teachings (30 to 60 minutes per week) If you have limited time or would like to stay focused on the essence of the Mahamudra path, we recommend you focus on the “Core Teachings” in each section. We have intentionally kept these selections brief so that even those with a very busy schedule can keep up.Going Deeper (1 to 3 hours per week) If you have more time and are interested in exploring the Mahamudra path in more depth, we recommend that you start with the “Core Teachings” and then pick one or more of the other course elements to go deeper. You can add the traditional and contemporary readings, or pick one of the view, meditation, or application sections from the workbook and complete the practices and exercises.The Full Experience (3 to 5 hours per week) If you have the time and are inspired to work with all of the readings, workbook exercises, and recommended practices, it will likely take you 3-4 hours per week for the study element, plus any additional time you spend working with the recommended practices and/or small group meetings.

5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.title: Basic Pronunciation Tips
5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.description:
Low toned sounds (ག་ཇ་ད་བ་) carry some aspiration on their own but lose it when combined w/ other letters. Thus, ག་ itself doesn't sound like the English "ga", more like a "gha".
ར་ is not like the American "R" sound, more like the Latin "R".
Unaspirated: ཀ་ཅ་ཏ་ཙ་
5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.sourcePath: 5. Tibetan Language Course/Reading Tibetan/Basic Pronunciation Tips.md

5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.title: Distinct Letter Combinations
5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.description:
When prefix ད་ comes before the root letter བ་, then it gets a high tone "wa" sound. If there is a YA-TAK (བྱ་) then it gets a high tone "ya" sound. If there is a RA-TAK (བྲ་) then it gets a high tone "ra" sound. With a shab-choo (བུ) it goes silent.
When prefixes འ་ and མ་ are in the 2nd syllable, they generally create a nasal sound (usually an "n" sound). A nasalized sound is also produced when ཟླ་ is the 2nd syllable, or if the second syllable has a LAN-GO superscript.
When བ་ is the 2nd or 3rd syllable of a word, it gets pronounced as "wa" (unless there is a shab-choo, ex. འབྲས་བུ)
5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.sourcePath: 5. Tibetan Language Course/Reading Tibetan/Distinct Letter Combinations.md

Post-Suffixes: ད་ ས་
You only ever see ས་
(Silent)

5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.title: Prefixes
5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.description:
Prefixes: ག་ ད་ བ་ མ་ འ་
Generally silent on their own
Spelling recitation order: Prefix + "Oh" (འོག་) + Root Letter (etc.) = Complete Sound
When there is a prefix, third column letters (ག་ཇ་ད་བ་ཛ་) lose aspiration and fourth column letters (ང་ཉ་ན་མ་ཡ་) gain high tone.

5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.title: Suffixes
5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.description: Suffixes: ག་ ང་ ད་ ན་ བ་ མ་ འ་ ར་ ལ་ ས་ Spelling recitation order: Root Letter + Suffix (etc.) = Complete Sound Suffixes are pronounced after the root letter w/o a vowel sound. "Special" suffixes ད་ ན་ ལ་ ས་ change the sound of the vowels ཨུ and ཨོ to umlaut sounds (ü and ö). They add a dreng-bhoo sound (ཨེ "eh") when there is no vowel marker. "Super special" suffixes ད་ and ས་ are silent (not pronounced after the root letter).

5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.title: The Four Tibetan Vowels
5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.description:
ཨི་ = This vowel is called kee-koo (གི་གུ་) spelt: "ah kee-koo eeh" ཨུ་ = This vowel is called shab-choo (ཞབས་ཀྱུ་) spelt: "ah shab-choo ooh"
ཨེ་ = This vowel is called dreng-bhoo (འགྲེང་བུ་) spelt: "ah dreng-bhoo eh"
ཨོ་ = This vowel is called na-ro (ན་རོ་) spelt: "ah na-ro oh"

5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.title: Connective Particle
5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.description:
They are: ཀྱི་གི་གྱི་འི་ཡི་ Show various kinds of connections/relationships between nouns, adjectives, and pronouns. You can often think of it as "belonging to", "possession", or "being including in" something. All have the same meaning/function, vary depending on spelling of word they follow (don't worry about this) Sometimes other prepositions in English may be more appropriate, but "of" is the best place to start. In that case, you'd translate the word order backwards from the Tibetan.

When there are personal pronouns (or persons' names) followed by a connective particle, then they can generally be translated as possessives. In that case, the word order will be similar to English.
If the first two won't make sense, try this one. When there is an adjective or a noun preceding the main noun w/ a connective particle, then it's often describing the main noun or acting as an adjective for it. I.e. describing what kind of person, place, or thing it is.

5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.description:
འདི་ means "this" and དེ་ means "that", which are placed after a noun and/or adjective.
རྣམས་ and དག་ are the two most common plural markers in written Tibetan, placed after a noun and/or adjective (as well as the འདི་ and དེ་ particles).
5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.sourcePath: 5. Tibetan Language Course/Tibetan Grammar/Important Modifiers.md

5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.title: Introduction to Tibetan Verbs
5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.description:
The main verb always comes at the end of a sentence. This means the typical sentence is structured as: Subject + Object + Verb.
A nominalized or infinitive verb ends w/ པ་ or བ་ (depending on the spelling). We could also more casually call that the "full form" of the verb. Although there are diff tenses of the verbs in Tibetan, we'll focus on the most commonly used verb tenses and then gradually work w/ diff tenses as they come up.
It's important to note the use of honorifics, which are especially prevalent in Dharmic language where the speaker generally wishes to show reverence to teachers and enlightened beings in particular. Thus, you'll see many verbs in their honorific forms which are crucial to identify as they are distinct from their non-honorific counterparts. Let's learn to feel the strength of reverence and devotion when we encounter honorifics!
We'll be emphasizing the presence and distinct usage of volitional and non-volitional verbs, which will be explained later. For now, know that volitional means you have control/agency/effort to make the action happen, whereas non-volitional means actions that occur w/o our control/agency/effort. Ex: སྐོར་ to turn volitionally འཁོར་ to turn non-volitionally We can sometimes refer to these verbs as transitive/intransitive or causative/resultative respectively, although these labels don't always precisely match.
5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.sourcePath: 5. Tibetan Language Course/Tibetan Grammar/Introduction to Tibetan Verbs.md

5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.title: Nouns and Adjectives in Tibetan
5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.description: (opposite order to English; noun comes before adjective)
5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.sourcePath: 5. Tibetan Language Course/Tibetan Grammar/Nouns and Adjectives in Tibetan.md

5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.title: The Verb of Identification
5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.description:
ཡིན་
Function: to identify, this is that.
It's like an = sign
I.e. a subject and predicate are equated with ཡིན་ (this = that).
When you see ཡིན་, ask yourself: "What is what?" or "What equals what?" as a guiding question. Then try to identify the subject and predicate.
Sometimes, ཡིན་ can be omitted from the sentence. when there is no verb it should be assumed that the verb is actually ཡིན་.
Sometimes the particle ནི་ is used to mark or emphasize the subject. In that case it does not need to be translated but is useful for identifying the subject. Clarifying role, organizational device ཡིན་ is the positive/affirmative form and མིན་/མ་ཡིན་ are the negative forms. Negating something The structure of a sentence w/ ཡིན་ is: A (subject) + B (predicate) + ཡིན་ (A=B)
5.-tibetan-language-course/tibetan-gramm.sourcePath: 5. Tibetan Language Course/Tibetan Grammar/The Verb of Identification.md

5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.title: Reading Tibetan
5.-tibetan-language-course/reading-tibet.description:
Spelling Recitation Order: Subscript Letter + Root Letter + TAK = Complete Sound YA-TAK
RA-TAK
LA-TAK (all "la", except: ཟླ་ pronounced "da")
WA-ZUR (no change to sound) Spelling Recitation Order: Superscript Letter + Root Letter + TAK = Complete Sound When ཀ་ཅ་ཏ་པ་ཙ་ receive a superscript there is no change in the original tone. When ག་ཇ་ད་བ་ཛ་ receive a superscript they lose aspiration. When ང་ཉ་ན་མ་ receive a superscript they have a higher tone.
RAN-GO, LAN-GO, SAN-GO (no change from root letter sounds other than main rules, with the exception of one of the LAN-GO's)
